{{distinguish|fluorene|fluoride}} {{Infobox fluorine}} '''Fluorine''' is a [[chemical element]] with symbol '''F''' and [[atomic number]] 9. It is the lightest [[halogen]] and exists as a highly toxic pale yellow [[diatomic molecule|diatomic]] gas at [[standard conditions for temperature and pressure|standard conditions]]. As the most [[electronegativity|electronegative]] element, it is extremely reactive, as it reacts with almost all other elements, except for helium and neon. Among the elements, fluorine ranks [[Abundance of the chemical elements|24th in universal abundance and 13th in terrestrial abundance]]. [[Fluorite]], the primary mineral source of fluorine which gave the element its name, was first described in 1529; as it was added to metal ores to lower their melting points for [[smelting]], the Latin verb ''{{lang|la|fluo}}'' meaning "flow" gave the mineral its name. Proposed as an element in 1810, fluorine proved difficult and dangerous to separate from its compounds, and several early experimenters died or sustained injuries from their attempts. Only in 1886 did French chemist [[Henri Moissan]] isolate elemental fluorine using low-temperature [[electrolysis]], a process still employed for modern production. Industrial production of fluorine gas for [[uranium enrichment]], its largest application, began during the [[Manhattan Project]] in [[World War II]]. Owing to the expense of refining pure fluorine, most commercial applications use fluorine compounds, with about half of mined fluorite used in [[steelmaking]]. The rest of the fluorite is converted into corrosive [[hydrogen fluoride]] en route to various organic fluorides, or into [[cryolite]] which plays a key role in [[Hall–Héroult process|aluminium refining]]. Organic fluorides have very high chemical and thermal stability; their major uses are as [[refrigerant]]s, electrical insulation and cookware, the last as [[polytetrafluoroethylene|PTFE]] (Teflon). Pharmaceuticals such as [[atorvastatin]] and [[fluoxetine]] also contain fluorine, and the [[fluoride|fluoride ion]] inhibits dental cavities, and so finds use in [[toothpaste]] and [[water fluoridation]]. [[fluorochemical industry|Global fluorochemical]] sales amount to more than [[United States dollar|US$]]15 billion a year. [[Fluorocarbon]] gases are generally [[greenhouse gas]]es with [[global-warming potential]]s 100 to 20,000 times that of [[carbon dioxide]]. [[Organofluorine compound]]s persist in the environment due to the strength of the [[carbon–fluorine bond]]. Fluorine has no known metabolic role in mammals; a few plants synthesize organofluorine poisons that deter herbivores. {{TOC limit|limit=3}} ==Characteristics== ===Electron configuration=== [[File:Fluorine shielding.svg|alt=Two concentric rings showing valence and non-valence electron shells|Simplified structure of the fluorine atom|left|thumb]] Fluorine atoms have nine electrons, one fewer than [[neon]], and [[electron configuration]] 1s22s22p5: two electrons in a filled inner shell and seven in an outer shell requiring one more to be filled. The outer electrons are ineffective at nuclear [[Shielding effect|shielding]], and experience a high [[effective nuclear charge]] of 9 − 2 = 7; this affects the atom's physical properties.{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|p=381}} Fluorine's [[ionization energy|first ionization energy]] is third-highest among all elements, behind helium and neon,{{sfn|Dean|1999|p=564}} which complicates the removal of electrons from neutral fluorine atoms. It also has a high [[electron affinity]], second only to [[chlorine]],{{sfn|Lide|2004|pp=10.137–10.138}} and tends to capture an electron to become [[isoelectronicity|isoelectronic]] with the noble gas neon;{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|p=381}} it has the highest [[electronegativity]] of any element.{{harvnb|Moore|Stanitski|Jurs|2010|p=[https://books.google.com/?id=ZOm8L9oCwLMC&pg=PA156 156]}}. Fluorine atoms have a small [[Covalent radius of fluorine|covalent radius]] of around 60 [[picometer]]s, similar to those of its [[period 2 element|period]] neighbors oxygen and neon.{{Harvnb|Cordero et al.|2008}}.{{Harvnb|Pyykkö|Atsumi|2009}}.{{refn|Sources disagree on the radii of oxygen, fluorine, and neon atoms. Precise comparison is thus impossible.||group="note"}} {{clear left}} ===Reactivity=== {{Main|Compounds of fluorine#Chemical characteristics of fluorine|l1=Chemical characteristics of fluorine}} The [[bond energy]] of [[Compounds of fluorine#Difluorine|difluorine]] is much lower than that of either {{chem|Cl|2}} or {{chem|Br|2}} and similar to the easily cleaved [[peroxide]] bond; this, along with high electronegativity, accounts for fluorine's easy dissociation, high reactivity, and strong bonds to non-fluorine atoms.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|p=804}}{{harvnb|Macomber|1996|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=HyuogOtzoaYC&pg=PA230 230]}} Conversely, bonds to other atoms are very strong because of fluorine's high electronegativity. Unreactive substances like powdered steel, glass fragments, and [[asbestos]] fibers react quickly with cold fluorine gas; wood and water spontaneously combust under a fluorine jet.{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|p=382}}{{harvnb|Nelson|1947}}. {{external media|width=240px|float=left|video1=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vtWp45Eewtw Bright flames] during fluorine reactions|video2 = Fluorine [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TLOFaWdPxB0 reacting with caesium]}} Reactions of elemental fluorine with metals require varying conditions. [[Alkali metal]]s cause explosions and [[alkaline earth metal]]s display vigorous activity in bulk; to prevent [[Passivation (chemistry)|passivation]] from the formation of metal fluoride layers, most other metals such as aluminium and iron must be powdered,{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|p=804}} and [[noble metal]]s require pure fluorine gas at 300–450 °C (575–850 °F).{{sfn|Lidin|Molochko|Andreeva|2000|pp=442–455}} Some solid nonmetals (sulfur, phosphorus) react vigorously in liquid air temperature fluorine.{{sfn|Wiberg|Wiberg|Holleman|2001|p=404}} [[Hydrogen sulfide]]{{sfn|Wiberg|Wiberg|Holleman|2001|p=404}} and [[sulfur dioxide]]{{sfn|Patnaik|2007|p=472}} combine readily with fluorine, the latter sometimes explosively; [[sulfuric acid]] exhibits much less activity, requiring elevated temperatures.{{sfn|Aigueperse et al.|2000|p=400}} [[Hydrogen]], like some of the alkali metals, reacts explosively with fluorine.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|pp=76, 804}} [[Carbon]], as [[lamp black]], reacts at room temperature to yield [[fluoromethane]]. Graphite combines with fluorine above 400 °C (750 °F) to produce [[non-stoichiometric compound|non-stoichiometric]] [[carbon monofluoride]]; higher temperatures generate gaseous [[fluorocarbon]]s, sometimes with explosions.{{harvnb|Kuriakose|Margrave|1965}}. Carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide react at or just above room temperature,{{harvnb|Hasegawa et al.|2007}}. whereas [[paraffin wax|paraffins]] and other organic chemicals generate strong reactions:{{harvnb|Lagow|1970|pp=64–78}}. even fully substituted [[haloalkane]]s such as [[carbon tetrachloride]], normally incombustible, may explode.{{harvnb|Navarrini et al.|2012}}. Although [[nitrogen trifluoride]] is stable, nitrogen requires an [[Electric discharge in gases|electric discharge]] at elevated temperatures for reaction with fluorine to occur, due to the very strong [[triple bond]] in elemental nitrogen;{{sfn|Lidin|Molochko|Andreeva|2000|p=252}} ammonia may react explosively.{{Harvnb|Tanner Industries|2011}}.{{harvnb|Morrow|Perry|Cohen|1959}}. Oxygen does not combine with fluorine under ambient conditions, but can be made to react using electric discharge at low temperatures and pressures; the products tend to disintegrate into their constituent elements when heated.{{harvnb|Emeléus|Sharpe|1974|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=qi0vujzNSz4C&pg=PA111 111]}}.{{sfn|Wiberg|Wiberg|Holleman|2001|p=457}}{{harvnb|Brantley|1949|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Yo7r_1qJG2gC&pg=PA26-IA83 26]}}. Heavier halogens{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|p=383}} react readily with fluorine as does the noble gas [[radon]];{{harvnb|Pitzer|1975}}. of the other noble gases, only [[xenon]] and [[krypton]] react, and only under special conditions.{{harvnb|Khriachtchev et al.|2000}}. {{clear left}} ===Phases=== {{main|Phases of fluorine}} [[File:Beta fluorine unit cell.svg|right|thumb|Crystal structure of β-fluorine. Spheres indicate {{chem|F|2}} molecules that may assume any angle. Other molecules are constrained to planes.|alt=Cube with spherical shapes on the corners and center and spinning molecules in planes in faces]] [[File:Beta-fluorine crystal structure.gif|thumb|Animation showing the crystal structure of beta-fluorine. Molecules on the faces of the unit cell have rotations constrained to a plane.]] At room temperature, fluorine is a gas of [[diatomic molecule]]s,{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|p=382}} pale yellow when pure (sometimes described as yellow-green).{{harvnb|Burdon|Emson|Edwards|1987}}. It has a characteristic pungent odor detectable at 20 [[parts per billion|ppb]].{{sfn|Lide|2004|p=4.12}} Fluorine condenses into a bright yellow liquid at −188 °C (−306 °F), a transition temperature similar to those of oxygen and nitrogen.{{sfn|Dean|1999|p=523}} Fluorine has two solid forms, α- and β-fluorine. The latter crystallizes at −220 °C (−364 °F) and is transparent and soft, with the same disordered [[Cubic crystal system|cubic]] structure of freshly crystallized solid oxygen,{{sfn|Dean|1999|p=523}}{{refn|α-Fluorine has a regular pattern of molecules and is a crystalline solid, but its molecules do not have a specific orientation. β-Fluorine's molecules have fixed locations and minimal rotational uncertainty. For further detail on α-fluorine, see the 1970 structure by Pauling.{{harvnb|Pauling|Keaveny|Robinson|1970}}. For further detail on the concept of disorder in crystals, see the referenced general reviews.{{harvnb|Bürgi|2000}}.{{harvnb|Müller|2009}}.||group="note"}} unlike the [[orthorhombic crystal system|orthorhombic]] systems of other solid halogens.{{sfn|Young|1975|p=10}} Further cooling to −228 °C (−378 °F) induces a [[phase transition]] into opaque and hard α-fluorine, which has a [[monoclinic crystal system|monoclinic]] structure with dense, angled layers of molecules. The transition from β- to α-fluorine is more [[exothermic]] than the condensation of fluorine, and can be violent.{{sfn|Young|1975|p=10}}{{harvnb|Barrett|Meyer|Wasserman|1967}}.{{refn|A loud click is heard. Samples may shatter and sample windows blow out.||group="note"}} ===Isotopes=== {{Main|Isotopes of fluorine}} Only one [[isotope]] of fluorine occurs naturally in abundance, the stable isotope {{chem|19|F}}.{{Harvnb|National Nuclear Data Center|NuDat 2.1|loc=[http://www.nndc.bnl.gov/nudat2/reCenter.jsp?z=9&n=10 Fluorine-19]}}. It has a high [[magnetogyric ratio]]{{refn|The ratio of the angular momentum to magnetic moment is called the gyromagnetic ratio. "Certain nuclei can for many purposes be thought of as spinning round an axis like the Earth or like a top. In general the spin endows them with angular momentum and with a magnetic moment; the first because of their mass, the second because all or part of their electric charge may be rotating with the mass."{{harvnb|Vigoureux|1961}}.|group="note"}} and exceptional sensitivity to magnetic fields; because it is also [[monoisotopic element|the only stable isotope]], it is [[Fluorine-19 nuclear magnetic resonance|used]] in [[magnetic resonance imaging]].{{harvnb|Meusinger|Chippendale|Fairhurst|2012|pp=752, 754}}. Seventeen [[radioisotope]]s with [[mass number]]s from 14 to 31 have been synthesized, of which [[Fluorine-18|{{chem|18|F}}]] is the most stable with a [[half-life]] of 109.77 minutes. Other radioisotopes have half-lives less than 70 seconds; most decay in less than half a second.{{Harvnb|National Nuclear Data Center|NuDat 2.1}}. The isotopes {{chem|17|F}} and {{chem|18|F}} undergo [[positron emission|β+ decay]] and [[electron capture]], lighter isotopes decay by [[proton emission]], and those heavier than {{chem|19|F}} undergo [[beta minus decay|β− decay]] (the heaviest ones with delayed [[neutron emission]]).{{harvnb|''NUBASE''|2016|p=030001-23—030001-27}}. Two [[nuclear isomer|metastable isomers]] of fluorine are known, {{chem|18m|F}}, with a half-life of 162(7) nanoseconds, and {{chem|26m|F}}, with a half-life of 2.2(1) milliseconds.{{harvnb|''NUBASE''|2016|pp=030001–24}}. ==Occurrence== {{Main|Origin and occurrence of fluorine}} ===Universe=== {| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin-left:15px; margin-top:0; font-size:10pt; line-height:11pt;" |+ style="margin-bottom: 5px;" | Solar System abundances{{harvnb|Cameron|1973}}. ! style="text-align:center;" | Atomic
number ! style="width:45%;"| Element ! style="padding-right: 5px; padding-left: 10px;" | Relative
amount |- | style="text-align:center;" | 6 | style="text-align:center;"| Carbon | style="padding-right:5px; text-align:right;"| 4,800 |- | style="text-align:center;" | 7 | style="text-align:center;"| Nitrogen | style="padding-right:5px; text-align:right;"|1,500 |- | style="text-align:center;" | 8 | style="text-align:center;"| Oxygen | style="padding-right:5px; text-align:right;"|8,800 |- style="background:#ff9;" | style="text-align:center;"| 9 | style="text-align:center; "| Fluorine | style="padding-right:5px; text-align:right;"|1 |- | style="text-align:center;" | 10 | style="text-align:center;"| Neon | style="padding-right:5px; text-align:right;"|1,400 |- | style="text-align:center;" | 11 | style="text-align:center;"| Sodium | style="padding-right:5px; text-align:right;"|24 |- | style="text-align:center;" | 12 | style="text-align:center;"| Magnesium | style="padding-right:5px; text-align:right;"|430 |} Among the lighter elements, fluorine's abundance value of 400 [[parts-per notation|ppb]] (parts per billion) – 24th among elements in the universe – is exceptionally low: other elements from carbon to magnesium are twenty or more times as common. This is because [[stellar nucleosynthesis]] processes bypass fluorine, and any fluorine atoms otherwise created have high [[nuclear cross section]]s, allowing further fusion with hydrogen or helium to generate oxygen or neon respectively.{{Harvnb|Clayton|2003|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=fXcdHyLUVnEC&pg=PA101 101–104]}}. Beyond this transient existence, three explanations have been proposed for the presence of fluorine:{{Harvnb|Croswell|2003}}.{{harvnb|Renda et al.|2004}}. * during [[type II supernova]]e, bombardment of neon atoms by [[neutrino]]s could transmute them to fluorine; * the solar wind of [[Wolf–Rayet star]]s could blow fluorine away from any hydrogen or helium atoms; or * fluorine is borne out on convection currents arising from fusion in [[asymptotic giant branch]] stars. ===Earth=== {{See also|List of countries by fluorite production}} Fluorine is the thirteenth most [[Abundance of elements in Earth's crust|common element in Earth's crust]] at 600–700 ppm (parts per million) by mass.{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|p=384}} Elemental fluorine in Earth's atmosphere would easily react with atmospheric [[water vapor]], precluding its natural occurrence;{{Harvnb|Schulze-Makuch|Irwin|2008|p=121}}.{{Harvnb|Haxel|Hedrick|Orris|2005}}. it is found only in combined mineral forms, of which [[fluorite]], [[fluorapatite]] and [[cryolite]] are the most industrially significant.{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|p=384}}{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|p=795}} Fluorite or fluorspar ({{chem|Ca|F|2}}), colorful and abundant worldwide, is fluorine's main source; China and Mexico are the major suppliers. The U.S. led extraction in the early 20th century but ceased mining in 1995.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|p=795}}{{harvnb|Villalba|Ayres|Schroder|2008}}.{{Harvnb|Kelly|Miller|2005}}.{{Harvnb|Lusty et al.|2008}}. Although fluorapatite (Ca5(PO4)3F) contains most of the world's fluorine, its low [[mass fraction (chemistry)|mass fraction]] of 3.5% means that most of it is used as a phosphate. In the U.S. small quantities of fluorine compounds are obtained via [[fluorosilicic acid]], a phosphate industry byproduct.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|p=795}} Cryolite ({{chem|Na|3|Al|F|6}}), once used directly in aluminium production, is the rarest and most concentrated of these three minerals. The main commercial mine on Greenland's west coast closed in 1987, and most cryolite is now synthesized.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|p=795}} {| cellpadding="3" style="margin:1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center;" |- | colspan="3" style="text-align:center;"| '''Major fluorine-containing minerals''' |- | [[File:Fluorite-270246.jpg|200px|alt=Pink globular mass with crystal facets]] | [[File:Apatite Canada.jpg|200px|alt=Long prism-like crystal, without luster, at an angle coming out of aggregate-like rock|Solid alpha-fluorine's crystal structure: fluorine molecules lie in shingled layers]] | [[File:Ivigtut cryolite edit.jpg|200px|alt=A parallelogram-shaped outline with space-filling diatomic molecules (joined circles) arranged in two layers]] |- style="text-align:center;" | Fluorite | Fluorapatite | Cryolite |} Other minerals such as [[topaz]] contain fluorine. Fluorides, unlike other halides, are insoluble and do not occur in commercially favorable concentrations in saline waters.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|p=795}} Trace quantities of organofluorines of uncertain origin have been detected in volcanic eruptions and geothermal springs.{{sfn|Gribble|2002}} The existence of gaseous fluorine in crystals, suggested by the smell of crushed [[antozonite]], is contentious;{{Harvnb|Richter|Hahn|Fuchs|2001|p=3}}.{{Harvnb|Schmedt|Mangstl|Kraus|2012}}. a 2012 study reported the presence of 0.04% {{chem|F|2}} by weight in antozonite, attributing these [[inclusion (mineral)|inclusions]] to radiation from the presence of tiny amounts of [[uranium]]. ==History== {{Main|History of fluorine}} ===Early discoveries=== [[File:Book9-25.gif|thumb|right|upright|alt=Woodcut image showing man at open hearth with tongs and machine bellows to the side in background, man at water-operated hammer with quenching sluice nearby in foreground|upright|Steelmaking illustration from ''[[De re metallica]]'']] In 1529, [[Georgius Agricola]] described fluorite as an additive used to lower the melting point of metals during [[smelting]].{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|p=790}}{{harvnb|Senning|2007|p=[https://books.google.com/?id=Fl4sdCYrq3cC&pg=PA149 149]}}.{{refn|[[Basilius Valentinus]] supposedly described fluorite in the late 15th century, but because his writings were uncovered 200 years later, this work's veracity is doubtful.{{Harvnb|Stillman|1912}}.{{harvnb|Principe|2012|pp=140, 145}}.{{Harvnb|Agricola|Hoover|Hoover|1912|loc=footnotes and commentary, pp. xxx, 38, 409, 430, 461, 608}}.||group="note"}} He penned the Latin word ''fluorés'' (''fluor,'' flow) for fluorite rocks. The name later evolved into ''fluorspar'' (still commonly used) and then ''fluorite''.{{harvnb|Norwood|Fohs|1907|p=[https://archive.org/stream/bulletin01kentgoog#page/n94/mode/2up 52]}}.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|p=109}}{{Harvnb|Agricola|Hoover|Hoover|1912|loc=preface, pp. [https://archive.org/stream/georgiusagricola00agririch#page/380/mode/2up 380–381]}}. The composition of fluorite was later determined to be [[calcium difluoride]].{{harvnb|Weeks|1932}}. [[Hydrofluoric acid]] was used in [[glass etching]] from 1720 onwards.{{refn|Or perhaps from as early as 1670 onwards; Partington{{harvnb|Partington|1923}}. and Weeks give differing accounts.||group="note"}} [[Andreas Sigismund Marggraf]] first characterized it in 1764 when he heated fluorite with sulfuric acid, and the resulting solution corroded its glass container.{{harvnb|Marggraf|1770}}. Swedish chemist [[Carl Wilhelm Scheele]] repeated the experiment in 1771, and named the acidic product ''fluss-spats-syran'' (fluorspar acid).{{harvnb|Scheele|1771}}. In 1810, the French physicist [[André-Marie Ampère]] suggested that hydrogen and an element analogous to chlorine constituted hydrofluoric acid.{{harvnb|Ampère|1816}}. [[Humphry Davy|Sir Humphry Davy]] proposed that this then-unknown substance be named ''fluorine'' from fluoric acid and the ''-ine'' suffix of other halogens. This word, with modifications, is used in most European languages; Greek, Russian, and some others (following Ampère's suggestion) use the name ''ftor'' or derivatives, from the Greek φθόριος (''phthorios'', destructive).{{sfn|Davy|1813|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=dhdGAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA278 278]}}{{sfn|Banks|1986|p=11}} The New Latin name ''fluorum'' gave the element its current symbol '''F'''; Fl was used in early papers.{{refn|Fl, since 2012, is used for [[flerovium]].||group="note"}} ===Isolation=== Initial studies on fluorine were so dangerous that several 19th-century experimenters were deemed "fluorine martyrs" after misfortunes with hydrofluoric acid.{{refn|[[Humphry Davy|Davy]], [[Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac|Gay-Lussac]], [[Louis Jacques Thénard|Thénard]], and the Irish chemists Thomas and George Knox were injured. Belgian chemist [[Paulin Louyet]] and French chemist [[Jérôme Nicklès]] died. Moissan also experienced serious hydrogen fluoride poisoning.||group="note"}} Isolation of elemental fluorine was hindered by the extreme corrosiveness of both elemental fluorine itself and hydrogen fluoride, as well as the lack of a simple and suitable [[electrolyte]]. [[Edmond Frémy]] postulated that [[electrolysis]] of pure hydrogen fluoride to generate fluorine was feasible and devised a method to produce anhydrous samples from acidified [[potassium bifluoride]]; instead, he discovered that the resulting (dry) hydrogen fluoride [[insulator (electricity)|did not conduct]] electricity.{{harvnb|Asimov|1966|p=162}}. Frémy's former student [[Henri Moissan]] persevered, and after much trial and error found that a mixture of potassium bifluoride and dry hydrogen fluoride was a conductor, enabling electrolysis. To prevent rapid corrosion of the platinum in his [[electrochemical cell]]s, he cooled the reaction to extremely low temperatures in a special bath and forged cells from a more resistant mixture of platinum and [[iridium]], and used fluorite stoppers.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|pp=789–791}} In 1886, after 74 years of effort by many chemists, Moissan isolated elemental fluorine.{{harvnb|Moissan|1886}}. In 1906, two months before his death, Moissan received the [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]],{{harvnb|Viel|Goldwhite|1993|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=jEy67gEvIuMC&pg=PA35 35]}}. with the following citation:{{harvnb|Toon|2011}}. {{quote|1=[I]n recognition of the great services rendered by him in his investigation and isolation of the element fluorine ... The whole world has admired the great experimental skill with which you have studied that savage beast among the elements.{{refn|Also honored was his invention of the [[electric arc furnace]].||group="note"}}}} Recherches sur l’isolement du fluor, Fig. 5.PNG|1887 drawing of Moissan's apparatus Henri Moissan HiRes.jpg|Nobel Prize photo of Moissan ===Later uses=== [[File:Uranium hexafluoride crystals sealed in an ampoule.jpg|right|An ampoule of [[uranium hexafluoride]] or ''hex''|thumb]] The [[Frigidaire]] division of [[General Motors]] (GM) experimented with chlorofluorocarbon refrigerants in the late 1920s, and [[Kinetic Chemicals]] was formed as a joint venture between GM and [[DuPont]] in 1930 hoping to market Freon-12 ({{chem|link=dichlorodifluoromethane|CCl|2|F|2}}) as one such [[refrigerant]]. It replaced earlier and more toxic compounds, increased demand for kitchen refrigerators, and became profitable; by 1949 DuPont had bought out Kinetic and marketed several other [[Freon]] compounds.{{harvnb|Okazoe|2009}}.{{sfn|Hounshell|Smith|1988|pp=156–157}}{{Harvnb|DuPont|2013a}}. [[Polytetrafluoroethylene]] (Teflon) was serendipitously discovered in 1938 by [[Roy J. Plunkett]] while working on refrigerants at Kinetic, and its superlative chemical and thermal resistance lent it to accelerated commercialization and mass production by 1941.{{sfn|Hounshell|Smith|1988|pp=156–157}} Large-scale production of elemental fluorine began during World War II. Germany used high-temperature electrolysis to make tons of the planned incendiary chlorine trifluoride{{harvnb|Meyer|1977|p=111}}. and the [[Manhattan Project]] used huge quantities to produce [[uranium hexafluoride]] for uranium enrichment. Since {{chem|UF|6}} is as corrosive as fluorine, [[gaseous diffusion]] plants required special materials: nickel for membranes, fluoropolymers for seals, and liquid fluorocarbons as coolants and lubricants. This burgeoning nuclear industry later drove post-war fluorochemical development.{{harvnb|Kirsch|2004|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=cqnEZSTA6cUC&pg=PA61 60–66]}}. ==Compounds== {{main|Compounds of fluorine}} Fluorine has a rich chemistry, encompassing organic and inorganic domains. It combines with metals, nonmetals, [[metalloid]]s, and most noble gases,{{harvnb|Riedel|Kaupp|2009}}. and usually assumes an [[oxidation state]] of −1.{{refn|Fluorine in {{chem|F|2}} is defined to have oxidation state 0. The unstable species {{chem|F|2|-}} and {{chem|F|3|-}}, which decompose at around 40 K, have intermediate oxidation states;{{sfn|Wiberg|Wiberg|Holleman|2001|p=422}} {{chem|F|4|+}} and a few related species are predicted to be stable.{{harvnb|Schlöder|Riedel|2012}}.|group="note"}} Fluorine's high electron affinity results in a preference for [[ionic bonding]]; when it forms [[covalent bond]]s, these are polar, and almost always [[single bond|single]].{{harvnb|Harbison|2002}}.{{harvnb|Edwards|1994|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=TRMRDXHWX7EC&pg=PA515 515]}}.The metastable [[boron monofluoride|boron]] and [[nitrogen monofluoride]] have higher-order fluorine bonds, and some [[metal complex]]es use it as a [[bridging ligand]]. [[Hydrogen bonding]] is another possibility. ===Metals=== {{See also|Fluoride volatility}} Alkali metals form ionic and highly soluble [[monofluoride]]s; these have the [[Cubic crystal system#Rock-salt structure|cubic arrangement of sodium chloride]] and analogous chlorides.{{harvnb|Katakuse et al.|1999|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=pjFTI5KgMFkC&pg=PA267 267]}}.{{sfn|Aigueperse et al.|2000|pp=420–422}} Alkaline earth [[difluoride]]s possess strong ionic bonds but are insoluble in water,{{harvnb|Storer|1864|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=KPyLb5f-p4EC&pg=PA278 278–280]}}. with the exception of [[beryllium difluoride]], which also exhibits some covalent character and has a [[silicon dioxide|quartz]]-like structure.{{harvnb|Walsh|2009|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=3-GbhmSfyeYC&pg=PA99 99–102], [https://books.google.com/books?id=3-GbhmSfyeYC&pg=PA118 118–119]}}. [[Rare earth element]]s and many other metals form mostly ionic [[trifluoride]]s.{{sfn|Emeléus|Sharpe|1983|pp=89–97}}{{harvnb|Babel|Tressaud|1985|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=SaWLysMGF3cC&pg=PA91 91–96]}}.{{harvnb|Einstein et al.|1967}}. Covalent bonding first comes to prominence in the [[tetrafluoride]]s: those of zirconium, hafnium{{harvnb|Brown et al.|2005|p=[https://books.google.com/?id=DvqwTdVhjMEC&pg=PA144 144]}}.{{harvnb|Perry|2011|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=SFD30BvPBhoC&pg=PA193 193]}}. and several actinides{{harvnb|Kern et al.|1994}}. are ionic with high melting points,{{sfn|Lide|2004|pp=4.60, 4.76, 4.92, 4.96}}{{refn|{{chem|Zr|F|4}} melts at 932 °C (1710 °F),{{sfn|Lide|2004|p=4.96}} {{chem|Hf|F|4}} sublimes at 968 °C (1774 °F), and {{chem|U|F|4}} melts at 1036 °C (1897 °F).{{sfn|Lide|2004|p=4.92}}|group="note"}} while those of titanium,{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|p=964}} vanadium,{{harvnb|Becker|Müller|1990}}. and niobium are polymeric,{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|p=990}} melting or decomposing at no more than 350 °C (660 °F).{{sfn|Lide|2004|pp=4.72, 4.91, 4.93}} [[Pentafluoride]]s continue this trend with their linear polymers and [[oligomer]]ic complexes.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|pp=561–563}}{{sfn|Emeléus|Sharpe|1983|pp=256–277}}{{sfn|Mackay|Mackay|Henderson|2002|pp=355–356}} Thirteen metal [[hexafluoride]]s are known,{{refn|These thirteen are those of molybdenum, technetium, ruthenium, rhodium, tungsten, rhenium, osmium, iridium, platinum, polonium, uranium, neptunium, and plutonium.|group="note"}} all octahedral, and are mostly volatile solids but for liquid {{chem|link=molybdenum hexafluoride|Mo|F|6}} and {{chem|link=rhenium hexafluoride|Re|F|6}}, and gaseous {{chem|link=tungsten hexafluoride|W|F|6}}.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|loc=(various pages, by metal in respective chapters)}}{{sfn|Lide|2004|pp=4.71, 4.78, 4.92}}{{harvnb|Drews et al.|2006}}. [[Rhenium heptafluoride]], the only characterized metal [[heptafluoride]], is a low-melting molecular solid with [[pentagonal bipyramidal molecular geometry]].{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|p=819}} Metal fluorides with more fluorine atoms are particularly reactive.{{harvnb|Bartlett|1962}}. {| cellpadding="3" style="margin:1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center;" |- | colspan="3" style="text-align:center;"|'''Structural progression of metal fluorides''' |- | [[File:Sodium-fluoride-unit-cell-3D.png|132px|alt=Checkerboard-like lattice of small blue and large yellow balls, going in three dimensions so that each ball has 6 nearest neighbors of opposite type|Sodium fluoride: cubic lattice of alternating sodium and fluorine atoms with no distinct molecules]] | [[File:Bismuth-pentafluoride-chain-from-xtal-1971-3D-balls.png|500px|alt=Straight chain of alternating balls, violet and yellow, with violet ones also linked to four more yellow perpendicularly to the chain and each other|Bismuth pentafluoride: arbitrarily long, straight chain of atoms]] | [[File:Rhenium-heptafluoride-3D-balls.png|121px|alt=Ball and stick drawing showing central violet ball with a yellow one directly above and below and then an equatorial belt of 5 surrounding yellow balls|Rhenium heptafluoride: discrete small molecule]] |- style="text-align:center;" | Sodium fluoride, ionic | Bismuth pentafluoride, polymeric | Rhenium heptafluoride, molecular |} ===Hydrogen=== {{Main|Hydrogen fluoride|hydrofluoric acid}} [[File:Boiling-points Chalcogen-Halogen.svg|alt=Graph showing water and hydrogen fluoride breaking the trend of lower boiling points for lighter molecules|Boiling points of hydrogen halides and chalcogenides, showing the unusually high values for hydrogen fluoride and water|thumb|right]] Hydrogen and fluorine combine to yield hydrogen fluoride, in which discrete molecules form clusters by hydrogen bonding, resembling water more than [[hydrogen chloride]].{{harvnb|Pauling|1960|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=L-1K9HmKmUUC&pg=PA454 454–464]}}.{{harvnb|Atkins|Jones|2007|pp=184–185}}.{{harvnb|Emsley|1981}}. It boils at a much higher temperature than heavier hydrogen halides and unlike them is fully [[miscible]] with water.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|pp=812–816}} Hydrogen fluoride readily hydrates on contact with water to form aqueous hydrogen fluoride, also known as hydrofluoric acid. Unlike the other hydrohalic acids, which are [[strong acids|strong]], hydrofluoric acid is a [[weak acid]] at low concentrations.{{sfn|Wiberg|Wiberg|Holleman|2001|p=425}}{{refn|See also the explanation by Clark.{{Harvnb|Clark|2002}}.|group="note"}} However, it can attack glass, something the other acids cannot do.{{harvnb|Chambers|Holliday|1975|pp=328–329}}. ===Other reactive nonmetals=== :''Metalloids are included in this section'' [[File:Chlorine-trifluoride-3D-balls.png|thumb|[[Chlorine trifluoride]], whose corrosive potential ignites asbestos, concrete, sand and other fire retardants{{sfn|Air Products and Chemicals|2004|p=1}}]] Binary fluorides of metalloids and p-block nonmetals are generally covalent and volatile, with varying reactivities. [[Period 3]] and heavier nonmetals can form [[hypervalent molecule|hypervalent]] fluorides.{{harvnb|Noury|Silvi|Gillespie|2002}}. [[Boron trifluoride]] is planar and possesses an incomplete octet. It functions as a [[Lewis acids and bases|Lewis acid]] and combines with Lewis bases like ammonia to form [[adduct]]s.{{harvnb|Chang|Goldsby|2013|p=706}}. [[Carbon tetrafluoride]] is tetrahedral and inert;{{refn|Carbon tetrafluoride is formally organic, but is included here rather than in the [[#Organic compounds|organofluorine chemistry section]] – where more complex carbon-fluorine compounds are discussed – for comparison with {{chem|Si|F|4}} and {{chem|Ge|F|4}}.|group="note"}} [[carbon group|its group]] analogues, silicon and germanium tetrafluoride, are also tetrahedral{{harvnb|Ellis|2001|p=69}}. but behave as Lewis acids.{{sfn|Aigueperse et al.|2000|p=423}}{{sfn|Wiberg|Wiberg|Holleman|2001|p=897}} The [[pnictogen]]s form trifluorides that increase in reactivity and basicity with higher molecular weight, although [[nitrogen trifluoride]] resists hydrolysis and is not basic.{{harvnb|Raghavan|1998|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=pBiS0jc-kWIC&pg=PA164 164–165]}}. The pentafluorides of phosphorus, arsenic, and antimony are more reactive than their respective trifluorides, with [[antimony pentafluoride]] the strongest neutral Lewis acid known.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|pp=561–563}}{{harvnb|Godfrey et al.|1998|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=vVhpurkfeN4C&pg=PA98 98]}}.{{sfn|Aigueperse et al.|2000|p=432}} [[Chalcogen]]s have diverse fluorides: unstable difluorides have been reported for oxygen (the only known compound with oxygen in an oxidation state of +2), sulfur, and selenium; tetrafluorides and hexafluorides exist for sulfur, selenium, and tellurium. The latter are stabilized by more fluorine atoms and lighter central atoms, so [[sulfur hexafluoride]] is especially inert.{{harvnb|Murthy|Mehdi Ali|Ashok|1995|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=0xl17YU8WzQC&pg=PA180 180–182], [https://books.google.com/books?id=0xl17YU8WzQC&pg=PA206 206–208]}}.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|pp=638–640, 683–689, 767–778}} Chlorine, bromine, and iodine can each form mono-, tri-, and pentafluorides, but only [[iodine heptafluoride]] has been characterized among possible [[interhalogen]] heptafluorides.{{sfn|Wiberg|Wiberg|Holleman|2001|pp=435–436}} Many of them are powerful sources of fluorine atoms, and industrial applications using chlorine trifluoride require precautions similar to those using fluorine.{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|pp=828–830}}{{harvnb|Patnaik|2007|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=-CRRJBVv5d0C&pg=PA478 478–479]}}. ===Noble gases=== {{main|Noble gas compound}} [[File:Xenon tetrafluoride crop.gif|thumb|left|alt=Black-and-white photo showing transparent crystals in a dish|These xenon tetrafluoride crystals were photographed in 1962. The compound's synthesis, as with xenon hexafluoroplatinate, surprised many chemists.{{sfn|Moeller|Bailar|Kleinberg|1980|p=236}}]] [[Noble gas]]es, having complete electron shells, defied reaction with other elements until 1962 when [[Neil Bartlett (chemist)|Neil Bartlett]] reported synthesis of [[xenon hexafluoroplatinate]];{{sfn|Wiberg|Wiberg|Holleman|2001|pp=392–393}} [[xenon difluoride]], [[xenon tetrafluoride|tetrafluoride]], [[xenon hexafluoride|hexafluoride]], and multiple oxyfluorides have been isolated since then.{{sfn|Wiberg|Wiberg|Holleman|2001|p=395–397, 400}} Among other noble gases, krypton forms a [[krypton difluoride|difluoride]],{{sfn|Lewars|2008|p=68}} and radon and fluorine generate a solid suspected to be [[radon difluoride]].{{harvnb|Pitzer|1993|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=CdUVspeIJAYC&pg=PA111 111]}}.{{sfn|Lewars|2008|p=67}} Binary fluorides of lighter noble gases are exceptionally unstable: argon and hydrogen fluoride combine under extreme conditions to give [[argon fluorohydride]]. Helium and neon have no long-lived fluorides,{{harvnb|Bihary|Chaban|Gerber|2002}}. and no neon fluoride has ever been observed;{{sfn|Lewars|2008|p=71}} helium fluorohydride has been detected for milliseconds at high pressures and low temperatures. ===Organic compounds=== {{main|Organofluorine chemistry}} [[File:FluorocarbonCrabFish.JPG|thumb|alt=Beaker with two layers of liquid, goldfish and crab in top, coin sunk in the bottom|[[miscibility|Immiscible]] layers of colored water (top) and much denser [[perfluoroheptane]] (bottom) in a beaker; a goldfish and crab cannot penetrate the boundary; [[Quarter (United States coin)|quarters]] rest at the bottom.]] [[File:Nafion2.svg|upright=1.0|thumb|alt=Skeletal chemical formula|Chemical structure of [[Nafion]], a fluoropolymer used in fuel cells and many other applications{{sfn|Hoogers|2004|pp=4–12}}]] The [[carbon–fluorine bond]] is [[organic chemistry]]'s strongest,{{harvnb|O'Hagan|2008}}. and gives stability to organofluorines.{{sfn|Siegemund et al.|2005|p=444}} It is almost non-existent in nature, but is used in artificial compounds. Research in this area is usually driven by commercial applications;{{Harvnb|Sandford|2000|p=455}}. the compounds involved are diverse and reflect the complexity inherent in organic chemistry. ====Discrete molecules==== {{main|Fluorocarbon|Perfluorinated compound}} The substitution of hydrogen atoms in an [[alkane]] by progressively more fluorine atoms gradually alters several properties: melting and boiling points are lowered, density increases, solubility in hydrocarbons decreases and overall stability increases. Perfluorocarbons,{{refn|''Perfluorocarbon'' and ''fluorocarbon'' are [[IUPAC]] synonyms for molecules containing carbon and fluorine only, but in colloquial and commercial contexts the latter term may refer to any carbon- and fluorine-containing molecule, possibly with other elements.|group="note"}} in which all hydrogen atoms are substituted, are insoluble in most organic solvents, reacting at ambient conditions only with sodium in liquid ammonia.{{sfn|Siegemund et al.|2005|pp=451–452}} The term ''[[perfluorinated compound]]'' is used for what would otherwise be a perfluorocarbon if not for the presence of a [[functional group]],{{harvnb|Barbee|McCormack|Vartanian|2000|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=EdzO0aUxDJkC&pg=PA116 116]}}.{{refn|This terminology is imprecise, and ''perfluorinated substance'' is also used.{{harvnb|Posner et al.|2013|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=dthjVAGP-XIC&pg=PA187&dq=%22Perfluorinated+compounds,+hydrocarbons+that+are+fully+fluorinated+except+for+one+functional+group%22 187–190]}}.|group="note"}} often a [[carboxylic acid]]. These compounds share many properties with perfluorocarbons such as stability and [[hydrophobicity]], while the functional group augments their reactivity, enabling them to adhere to surfaces or act as [[surfactant]]s;{{Harvnb|Salager|2002|p=45}}. [[Fluorosurfactant]]s, in particular, can lower the [[surface tension]] of water more than their hydrocarbon-based analogues. [[Fluorotelomer]]s, which have some unfluorinated carbon atoms near the functional group, are also regarded as perfluorinated.{{harvnb|Posner|2011|p=27}}. ====Polymers==== Polymers exhibit the same stability increases afforded by fluorine substitution (for hydrogen) in discrete molecules; their melting points generally increase too.{{sfn|Carlson|Scmiegel|2005|p=3}} [[Polytetrafluoroethylene]] (PTFE), the simplest fluoropolymer and perfluoro analogue of [[polyethylene]] with [[structural unit]] –{{chem|C|F|2}}–, demonstrates this change as expected, but its very high melting point makes it difficult to mold.{{sfn|Carlson|Scmiegel|2005|pp=3–4}} Various PTFE derivatives are less temperature-tolerant but easier to mold: [[fluorinated ethylene propylene]] replaces some fluorine atoms with [[trifluoromethyl]] groups, [[perfluoroalkoxy alkane]]s do the same with [[trifluoromethoxy]] groups,{{sfn|Carlson|Scmiegel|2005|pp=3–4}} and [[Nafion]] contains perfluoroether side chains capped with [[sulfonic acid]] groups.{{harvnb|Rhoades|2008|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=k3AoGn0upf0C&pg=PA2 2]}}.{{harvnb|Okada et al.|1998}}. Other fluoropolymers retain some hydrogen atoms; [[polyvinylidene fluoride]] has half the fluorine atoms of PTFE and [[polyvinyl fluoride]] has a quarter, but both behave much like perfluorinated polymers.{{sfn|Carlson|Scmiegel|2005|p=4}} ==Production== ===Industrial=== [[File:Fluorine cell room.jpg|thumb|Industrial fluorine cells at [[City of Preston, Lancashire|Preston]]|alt=A machine room]] Moissan's method is used to produce industrial quantities of fluorine, via the electrolysis of a [[potassium fluoride]]/[[hydrogen fluoride]] mixture: hydrogen and fluoride ions are reduced and oxidized at a steel container [[cathode]] and a carbon block [[anode]], under 8–12 volts, to generate hydrogen and fluorine gas respectively.{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|p=386}} Temperatures are elevated, KF•2HF melting at {{convert|70|Celsius}} and being electrolyzed at {{convert|70|–|130|Celsius}}. KF, which acts as catalyst, is essential since pure HF cannot be electrolyzed.{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|pp=384–285}}{{sfn|Greenwood|Earnshaw|1998|pp=796–797}} Fluorine can be stored in steel cylinders that have passivated interiors, at temperatures below {{convert|200|Celsius}}; otherwise nickel can be used.{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|pp=384–385}} Regulator valves and pipework are made of nickel, the latter possibly using [[Monel]] instead.{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|pp=390–391}} Frequent passivation, along with the strict exclusion of water and greases, must be undertaken. In the laboratory, glassware may carry fluorine gas under low pressure and anhydrous conditions;{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|pp=390–391}} some sources instead recommend nickel-Monel-PTFE systems.{{harvnb|Shriver|Atkins|2010|p=427}}. ===Chemical=== While preparing for a 1986 conference to celebrate the centennial of Moissan's achievement, [[Karl O. Christe]] reasoned that chemical fluorine generation should be feasible since some metal fluoride anions have no stable neutral counterparts; their acidification potentially triggers oxidation instead. He devised a method which evolves fluorine at high yield and atmospheric pressure:{{harvnb|Christe|1986}}. :2 [[Potassium permanganate|KMnO4]] + 2 [[Potassium fluoride|KF]] + 10 [[Hydrogen fluoride|HF]] + 3 [[Hydrogen peroxide|H2O2]] → 2 K2MnF6 + 8 [[Water|H2O]] + 3 [[Molecular oxygen|O2]]↑ :2 K2MnF6 + 4 [[Antimony pentafluoride|SbF5]] → 4 KSbF6 + 2 MnF3 + F2↑ Christe later commented that the reactants "had been known for more than 100 years and even Moissan could have come up with this scheme."{{Harvnb|Christe Research Group|n.d.}} As late as 2008, some references still asserted that fluorine was too reactive for any chemical isolation.{{harvnb|Carey|2008|page=173}}. ==Industrial applications== {{Main|Fluorochemical industry}} Fluorite mining, which supplies most global fluorine, peaked in 1989 when 5.6 million [[metric ton]]s of ore were extracted. Chlorofluorocarbon restrictions lowered this to 3.6 million tons in 1994; production has since been increasing. Around 4.5 million tons of ore and revenue of [[United States dollar|US$]]550 million were generated in 2003; later reports estimated 2011 global fluorochemical sales at $15 billion and predicted 2016–18 production figures of 3.5 to 5.9 million tons, and revenue of at least $20 billion.{{harvnb|Kirsch|2004|pp=3–10}}.{{Harvnb|Miller|2003b}}.{{Harvnb|PRWeb|2012}}.{{Harvnb|Bombourg|2012}}.{{Harvnb|TMR|2013}}. [[Froth flotation]] separates mined fluorite into two main metallurgical grades of equal proportion: 60–85% pure metspar is almost all used in iron smelting whereas 97%+ pure acidspar is mainly converted to the key industrial [[chemical intermediate|intermediate]] hydrogen fluoride.{{harvnb|Fulton|Miller|2006|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=zNicdkuulE4C&pg=PA471 471]}}. Image:The fluorine economy.svg|thumb|675px|center|Clickable diagram of the fluorochemical industry according to mass flows rect 9 6 81 34 [[Fluorite]] rect 9 172 81 199 [[Fluorapatite]] rect 142 5 244 34 [[Hydrogen fluoride]] rect 142 65 245 97 [[Smelting|Metal smelting]] rect 142 121 244 154 [[Glass production]] rect 309 5 411 33 [[Organofluorine|Fluorocarbons]] rect 310 63 413 92 [[Sodium hexafluoroaluminate]] rect 311 121 414 154 [[Pickling (metal)]] rect 310 171 412 200 [[Hexafluorosilicic acid|Fluorosilicic acid]] rect 309 211 412 243 [[Cracking (chemistry)|Alkane cracking]] rect 483 6 585 34 [[Hydrofluorocarbon]]s rect 484 47 585 76 [[Chlorofluorocarbon#Development of alternatives for CFCs|Hydrochlorofluorocarbons]] rect 483 88 586 116 [[Chlorofluorocarbon]] rect 483 128 585 160 [[Polytetrafluoroethylene|Teflon]] rect 484 170 586 200 [[Water fluoridation]] rect 483 210 586 238 [[Enriched uranium|Uranium enrichment]] rect 484 258 586 287 [[Sulfur hexafluoride]] rect 484 297 585 357 [[Tungsten hexafluoride]] rect 28 246 177 293 [[Phosphogypsum]] desc bottom-left [[File:SF6 current transformer TGFM-110 Russia.jpg|thumb|alt=Minaret-like electrical devices with wires around them, thicker at the bottom|{{chem|SF|6}} transformers at a Russian railway]] {{see also|Industrial gas}} At least 17,000 metric tons of fluorine are produced each year. It costs only $5–8 per kilogram as uranium or sulfur hexafluoride, but many times more as an element because of handling challenges. Most processes using free fluorine in large amounts employ ''in situ'' generation under [[vertical integration]].{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|p=392}} The largest application of fluorine gas, consuming up to 7,000 metric tons annually, is in the preparation of {{chem|UF|6}} for the [[nuclear fuel cycle]]. Fluorine is used to fluorinate [[uranium tetrafluoride]], itself formed from uranium dioxide and hydrofluoric acid.{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|p=392}} Fluorine is monoisotopic, so any mass differences between {{chem|UF|6}} molecules are due to the presence of {{chem|235|U}} or {{chem|238|U}}, enabling uranium enrichment via gaseous diffusion or [[gas centrifuge]].{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|p=382}} About 6,000 metric tons per year go into producing the inert [[dielectric]] {{chem|SF|6}} for high-voltage transformers and circuit breakers, eliminating the need for hazardous [[polychlorinated biphenyl]]s associated with {{nowrap|oil-filled}} devices.{{sfn|Aigueperse et al.|2000|p=430}} Several fluorine compounds are used in electronics: rhenium and tungsten hexafluoride in [[chemical vapor deposition]], [[tetrafluoromethane]] in [[plasma etching]]{{sfn|Jaccaud et al.|2000|pp=391–392}}{{harvnb|El-Kareh|1994|p=[https://books.google.com/?id=Wg1SnT6Cb0QC&pg=PA317 317]}}.{{harvnb|Arana et al.|2007}}. and [[nitrogen trifluoride]] in cleaning equipment. Fluorine is also used in the synthesis of organic fluorides, but its reactivity often necessitates conversion first to the gentler {{chem|Cl|F|3}}, {{chem|Br|F|3}}, or {{chem|I|F|5}}, which together allow calibrated fluorination. Fluorinated pharmaceuticals use [[sulfur tetrafluoride]] instead. ===Inorganic fluorides=== [[File:Hall-Heroult cell schematic.svg|thumb|Aluminium extraction depends critically on cryolite]] As with other iron alloys, around 3 kg (6.5 lb) metspar is added to each metric ton of steel; the fluoride ions lower its melting point and [[viscosity]].{{Harvnb|Miller|2003a}}. Alongside its role as an additive in materials like enamels and welding rod coats, most acidspar is reacted with sulfuric acid to form hydrofluoric acid, which is used in steel [[Pickling (metal)|pickling]], glass etching and [[cracking (chemistry)|alkane cracking]]. One-third of HF goes into synthesizing [[sodium hexafluoroaluminate|cryolite]] and [[aluminium trifluoride]], both fluxes in the [[Hall–Héroult process]] for aluminium extraction; replenishment is necessitated by their occasional reactions with the smelting apparatus. Each metric ton of aluminium requires about 23 kg (51 lb) of flux.{{Harvnb|Energetics, Inc.|1997|pp=41, 50}}. Fluorosilicates consume the second largest portion, with [[sodium fluorosilicate]] used in water fluoridation and laundry effluent treatment, and as an intermediate en route to cryolite and silicon tetrafluoride.{{sfn|Aigueperse et al.|2000|p=428}} Other important inorganic fluorides include those of [[cobalt difluoride|cobalt]], [[nickel difluoride|nickel]], and [[ammonium fluoride|ammonium]].{{sfn|Aigueperse et al.|2000|pp=420–422}}{{harvnb|Willey|2007|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=PrKemPXyXNIC&pg=PA113 113]}}. ===Organic fluorides=== Organofluorides consume over 20% of mined fluorite and over 40% of hydrofluoric acid, with [[#Refrigerant gases|refrigerant gases]] dominating and [[#Fluoropolymers|fluoropolymers]] increasing their market share.{{Harvnb|PRWeb|2010}}. [[#Surfactants|Surfactants]] are a minor application but generate over $1 billion in annual revenue.{{harvnb|Renner|2006}}. Due to the danger from direct hydrocarbon–fluorine reactions above −150 °C (−240 °F), industrial fluorocarbon production is indirect, mostly through [[Finkelstein reaction|halogen exchange reactions]] such as [[Swarts fluorination]], in which chlorocarbon chlorines are substituted for fluorines by hydrogen fluoride under catalysts. [[Electrochemical fluorination]] subjects hydrocarbons to electrolysis in hydrogen fluoride, and the [[Fowler process]] treats them with solid fluorine carriers like [[cobalt trifluoride]].{{Harvnb|Green|Slinn|Simpson|Woytek|1994|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=TRMRDXHWX7EC&pg=PA91&lpg=PA91 91–93]}}. ====Refrigerant gases==== {{See also|Refrigerant}} Halogenated refrigerants, termed Freons in informal contexts,{{refn|This DuPont trademark is sometimes further misused for CFCs, HFCs, or HCFCs.||group="note"}} are identified by [[Refrigerant#Refrigerants by class and R-number|R-numbers]] that denote the amount of fluorine, chlorine, carbon, and hydrogen present.{{Harvnb|DuPont|2013b}}. [[Chlorofluorocarbons]] (CFCs) like [[trichlorofluoromethane|R-11]], [[dichlorodifluoromethane|R-12]], and [[1,2-dichlorotetrafluoroethane|R-114]] once dominated organofluorines, peaking in production in the 1980s. Used for air conditioning systems, propellants and solvents, their production was below one-tenth of this peak by the early 2000s, after widespread international prohibition. Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) were designed as replacements; their synthesis consumes more than 90% of the fluorine in the organic industry. Important HCFCs include R-22, [[chlorodifluoromethane]], and [[1,1-Dichloro-1-fluoroethane|R-141b]]. The main HFC is [[1,1,1,2-Tetrafluoroethane|R-134a]] with a new type of molecule [[2,3,3,3-Tetrafluoropropene|HFO-1234yf]], a [[Hydrofluoroolefin]] (HFO) coming to prominence owing to its [[global warming potential]] of less than 1% that of HFC-134a.{{harvnb|Walter|2013}}. ====Polymers==== [[File:A water droplet DWR-coated surface2 edit1.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Shiny spherical drop of water on blue cloth|Fluorosurfactant-treated fabrics are often [[hydrophobe|hydrophobic]]]] {{Main|Fluoropolymer}} About 180,000 metric tons of fluoropolymers were produced in 2006 and 2007, generating over $3.5 billion revenue per year.{{harvnb|Buznik|2009}}. The global market was estimated at just under $6 billion in 2011 and was predicted to grow by 6.5% per year up to 2016.{{Harvnb|PRWeb|2013}}. Fluoropolymers can only be formed by [[polymerization|polymerizing]] free radicals.{{sfn|Carlson|Scmiegel|2005|p=3}} Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), sometimes called by its DuPont name Teflon, represents 60–80% by mass of the world's fluoropolymer production. The largest application is in [[electrical insulation]] since PTFE is an excellent [[dielectric]]. It is also used in the chemical industry where corrosion resistance is needed, in coating pipes, tubing, and gaskets. Another major use is in PFTE-coated [[fabric structure|fiberglass cloth]] for stadium roofs. The major consumer application is for [[non-stick surface|non-stick cookware]].{{Harvnb|Martin|2007|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=xv420pEC2qMC&pg=PA189 187–194]}}. Jerked PTFE film becomes expanded PTFE (ePTFE), a fine-pored [[synthetic membrane|membrane]] sometimes referred to by the brand name [[Gore-Tex]] and used for rainwear, [[personal protective equipment|protective apparel]], and [[filtration|filters]]; [[PTFE fiber|ePTFE fibers]] may be made into [[seal (mechanical)|seals]] and [[Dust collector|dust filters]]. Other fluoropolymers, including [[fluorinated ethylene propylene]], mimic PTFE's properties and can substitute for it; they are more moldable, but also more costly and have lower thermal stability. Films from two different fluoropolymers replace glass in solar cells.{{harvnb|DeBergalis|2004}}. The chemically resistant (but expensive) fluorinated [[ionomer]]s are used as electrochemical cell membranes, of which the first and most prominent example is [[Nafion]]. Developed in the 1960s, it was initially deployed as fuel cell material in spacecraft and then replaced mercury-based [[chloralkali process]] cells. Recently, the fuel cell application has reemerged with efforts to install [[proton exchange membrane]] fuel cells into automobiles.{{harvnb|Grot|2011|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=E8H1Hwd5GXUC&pg=PA6 1–10]}}.{{harvnb|Ramkumar|2012|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=ep7U5G4O3mQC&pg=PA567 567]}}.{{harvnb|Burney|1999|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=rtm_bjQd8SUC&pg=PA111 111]}}. [[Fluoroelastomer]]s such as [[Viton]] are [[crosslink]]ed fluoropolymer mixtures mainly used in [[O-ring]]s; [[perfluorobutane]] (C4F10) is used as a fire-extinguishing agent.{{sfn|Slye|2012|p=10}} ====Surfactants==== {{Main|Fluorinated surfactant|Durable water repellent}} Fluorosurfactants are small organofluorine molecules used for repelling water and stains. Although expensive (comparable to pharmaceuticals at $200–2000 per kilogram), they yielded over $1 billion in annual revenues by 2006; [[Scotchgard]] alone generated over $300 million in 2000.{{Harvnb|Kissa|2001|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=iAmE8v3bFnUC&pg=PA522 516–551]}}.{{Harvnb|Ullmann|2008|pp=538, 543–547}}. Fluorosurfactants are a minority in the overall surfactant market, most of which is taken up by much cheaper hydrocarbon-based products. Applications in [[surfactants in paint|paints]] are burdened by [[compounding]] costs; this use was valued at only $100 million in 2006. ====Agrichemicals==== About 30% of [[agrichemical]]s contain fluorine,{{Harvnb|ICIS|2006}}. most of them [[herbicide]]s and [[fungicide]]s with a few [[plant hormone|crop regulators]]. Fluorine substitution, usually of a single atom or at most a [[trifluoromethyl]] group, is a robust modification with effects analogous to fluorinated pharmaceuticals: increased biological stay time, membrane crossing, and altering of molecular recognition. [[Trifluralin]] is a prominent example, with large-scale use in the U.S. as a weedkiller,{{harvnb|Theodoridis|2006}}.{{Harvnb|EPA|1996}}. but it is a suspected carcinogen and has been banned in many European countries.{{Harvnb|DG Environment|2007}}. [[Sodium monofluoroacetate]] (1080) is a mammalian poison in which two [[acetic acid]] hydrogens are replaced with fluorine and sodium; it disrupts cell metabolism by replacing acetate in the [[citric acid cycle]]. First synthesized in the late 19th century, it was recognized as an insecticide in the early 20th, and was later deployed in its current use. New Zealand, the largest consumer of 1080, uses it to protect [[kiwi]]s from the invasive Australian [[common brushtail possum]].{{Harvnb|Beasley|2002}}. Europe and the U.S. have banned 1080.{{Harvnb|Eisler|1995}}.{{refn|American sheep and cattle collars may use 1080 against predators like coyotes.||group="note"}} ==Medicinal applications== ===Dental care=== [[File:US Navy 090526-F-1333S-023 A service member embarked aboard the Military Sealift Command hospital ship USNS Comfort (T-AH 20) gives a Fluoride treatment to a patient during a Continuing Promise 2009 medical civil service projec.jpg|thumb|alt=Man holding plastic tray with brown material in it and sticking a small stick into a boy's open mouth|Topical fluoride treatment in Panama]] {{Main|Fluoride therapy|Water fluoridation|Water fluoridation controversy}} Population studies from the mid-20th century onwards show [[topical medication|topical]] fluoride reduces [[dental caries]]. This was first attributed to the conversion of tooth enamel [[hydroxyapatite]] into the more durable fluorapatite, but studies on pre-fluoridated teeth refuted this hypothesis, and current theories involve fluoride aiding enamel growth in small caries.{{harvnb|Pizzo|2007}}. After studies of children in areas where fluoride was naturally present in drinking water, controlled [[water supply|public water supply]] fluoridation to fight tooth decay{{Harvnb|CDC|2001}}. began in the 1940s and is now applied to water supplying 6 percent of the global population, including two-thirds of Americans.{{harvnb|Ripa|1993}}.{{harvnb|Cheng|Chalmers|Sheldon|2007}}. Reviews of the scholarly literature in 2000 and 2007 associated water fluoridation with a significant reduction of tooth decay in children.{{harvnb|NHMRC|2007}}; see {{harvnb|Yeung|2008}} for a summary. Despite such endorsements and evidence of no adverse effects other than mostly benign [[dental fluorosis]],{{harvnb|Marya|2011|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=NKYy0w1OjJoC&pg=PA343 343]}}. [[water fluoridation controversy|opposition]] still exists on ethical and safety grounds.{{harvnb|Armfield|2007}}. The benefits of fluoridation have lessened, possibly due to other fluoride sources, but are still measurable in low-income groups. [[Sodium monofluorophosphate]] and sometimes sodium or [[tin(II) fluoride]] are often found in fluoride [[toothpaste]]s, first introduced in the U.S. in 1955 and now ubiquitous in developed countries, alongside fluoridated mouthwashes, gels, foams, and varnishes.{{harvnb|Baelum|Sheiham|Burt|2008|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=fZfXWhSmG1UC&pg=PA518 518]}}.{{Harvnb|Cracher|2012|p=12}}. ===Pharmaceuticals=== [[File:Prozac pills.jpg|thumb|alt=Capsules with "Prozac" and "DISTA" visible|[[Fluoxetine]] capsules]] Twenty percent of modern pharmaceuticals contain fluorine.{{harvnb|Emsley|2011|p=178}}. One of these, the cholesterol-reducer [[atorvastatin]] (Lipitor), made more revenue than any other drug until it became generic in 2011.{{Harvnb|Johnson|2011}}. The combination asthma prescription [[Seretide]], a top-ten revenue drug in the mid-2000s, contains two active ingredients, one of which – [[fluticasone]] – is fluorinated. Many drugs are fluorinated to delay inactivation and lengthen dosage periods because the carbon–fluorine bond is very stable.{{harvnb|Hagmann|2008}}. Fluorination also increases [[lipophilicity]] because the bond is more hydrophobic than the [[carbon–hydrogen bond]], and this often helps in cell membrane penetration and hence [[bioavailability]].{{harvnb|Swinson|2005}}. [[Tricyclic antidepressant|Tricyclics]] and other pre-1980s [[antidepressant]]s had several side effects due to their non-selective interference with [[neurotransmitter]]s other than the [[serotonin]] target; the fluorinated [[fluoxetine]] was selective and one of the first to avoid this problem. Many current antidepressants receive this same treatment, including the [[selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor]]s: [[citalopram]], its isomer [[escitalopram]], and [[fluvoxamine]] and [[paroxetine]].{{Harvnb|Mitchell|2004|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Duy5_XAD-vgC&pg=PA37 37–39]}}.{{Harvnb|Preskorn|1996|loc=[http://www.preskorn.com/books/ssri_s2.html chap. 2]}}. [[Quinolones]] are artificial [[broad-spectrum antibiotic]]s that are often fluorinated to enhance their effects. These include [[ciprofloxacin]] and [[levofloxacin]].{{harvnb|Werner et al.|2011}}.{{Harvnb|Brody|2012}}.{{harvnb|Nelson et al.|2007}}.{{harvnb|King|Malone|Lilley|2000}}. Fluorine also finds use in steroids:{{harvnb|Parente|2001|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=fsfnKeFflUoC&pg=PA40 40]}}. [[fludrocortisone]] is a blood pressure-raising [[mineralocorticoid]], and [[triamcinolone]] and [[dexamethasone]] are strong [[glucocorticoid]]s.{{harvnb|Raj|Erdine|2012|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=SQDge93GucMC&pg=PA58 58]}}. The majority of inhaled [[anesthetic]]s are heavily fluorinated; the prototype [[halothane]] is much more inert and potent than its contemporaries. Later compounds such as the fluorinated [[ether]]s [[sevoflurane]] and [[desflurane]] are better than halothane and are almost insoluble in blood, allowing faster waking times.{{harvnb|Filler|Saha|2009}}.{{harvnb|Bégué|Bonnet-Delpon|2008|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=QMVSvZ-R7I0C&pg=PA335 335–336]}}. ===PET scanning=== {{main|Positron emission tomography}} [[File:PET-MIPS-anim.gif|thumb|upright|A full-body {{chem|18|F}} PET scan with glucose tagged with radioactive fluorine-18. The normal brain and kidneys take up enough glucose to be imaged. the A malignant tumor is seen in the upper abdomen. Radioactive fluorine is seen in urine in the bladder.|alt=Rotating transparent image of a human figure with targeted organs highlighted]] Fluorine-18 is often found in [[radioactive tracer]]s for positron emission tomography, as its half-life of almost two hours is long enough to allow for its transport from production facilities to imaging centers.{{harvnb|Schmitz et al.|2000}}. The most common tracer is [[fluorodeoxyglucose]] which, after intravenous injection, is taken up by glucose-requiring tissues such as the brain and most malignant tumors;{{harvnb|Bustamante|Pedersen|1977}}. [[X-ray computed tomography|computer-assisted tomography]] can then be used for detailed imaging.{{harvnb|Alavi|Huang|2007|p=41}}. ===Oxygen carriers=== {{see also|Blood substitute|Liquid breathing}} Liquid fluorocarbons can hold large volumes of oxygen or carbon dioxide, more so than blood, and have attracted attention for their possible uses in artificial blood and in liquid breathing.{{harvnb|Gabriel et al.|1996}}. Because fluorocarbons do not normally mix with water, they must be mixed into emulsions (small droplets of perfluorocarbon suspended in water) to be used as blood.{{Harvnb|Sarkar|2008}}.{{Harvnb|Schimmeyer|2002}}. One such product, [[Oxycyte]], has been through initial clinical trials.{{Harvnb|Davis|2006}}. These substances can aid endurance athletes and are banned from sports; one cyclist's near death in 1998 prompted an investigation into their abuse.{{Harvnb|Gains|1998}}.{{Harvnb|Taber|1999}}. Applications of pure perfluorocarbon liquid breathing (which uses pure perfluorocarbon liquid, not a water emulsion) include assisting burn victims and premature babies with deficient lungs. Partial and complete lung filling have been considered, though only the former has had any significant tests in humans.{{Harvnb|Shaffer|Wolfson|Clark|1992|p=102}}. An Alliance Pharmaceuticals effort reached clinical trials but was abandoned because the results were not better than normal therapies.{{harvnb|Kacmarek et al.|2006}}. ==Biological role== {{Main|Biological aspects of fluorine}} [[File:Gifblaar.jpg|thumb|The [[gifblaar]] is one of the few organofluorine-synthesizing organisms]] Fluorine is [[micronutrient|not essential]] for humans or other mammals; small amounts may be beneficial for bone strength, but this has not been definitively established. As there are many environmental sources of trace fluorine, the possibility of a [[fluorine deficiency]] could apply only to artificial diets.{{harvnb|Nielsen|2009}}.{{Harvnb|Olivares|Uauy|2004}}. Natural organofluorines have been found in microorganisms and plants{{sfn|Gribble|2002}} but not animals.{{harvnb|Murphy|Schaffrath|O'Hagan|2003}} The most common is [[sodium fluoroacetate|fluoroacetate]], which is used as a [[plant defense against herbivory|defense against herbivores]] by at least 40 plants in Africa, Australia and Brazil.{{harvnb|Proudfoot|Bradberry|Vale|2006}}. Other examples include terminally fluorinated [[fatty acid]]s, [[fluoroacetone]], and 2-fluorocitrate. An enzyme that binds fluorine to carbon – [[adenosyl-fluoride synthase]] – was discovered in bacteria in 2002.{{harvnb|O'Hagan et al.|2002}}. ==Toxicity== {{main|Biological aspects of fluorine#Hazards|l1=Fluorine-related hazards}} {{multiple image | align = left | footer = U.S. hazard signs for commercially transported fluorine[[#NOAASheet|National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]. | width = 60 | image1 = DOT hazmat class 6.1.svg | alt1 = A diagonal placard with warning poison | image2 = DOT hazmat class 5.1.svg | alt2 = A diagonal placard with warning corrosive | image3 = DOT hazmat class 8.svg | alt3 = A diagonal placard with warning inhalant | image4 = DOT hazmat class 2.3 (alt).svg | alt4 = A diagonal placard with warning oxidant }} Elemental fluorine is highly toxic to living organisms. Its effects in humans start at concentrations lower than [[hydrogen cyanide]]'s 50 ppm{{harvnb|The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|1994a}}. and are similar to those of chlorine:{{harvnb|The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|1994b}}. significant irritation of the eyes and respiratory system as well as liver and kidney damage occur above 25 ppm, which is the [[IDLH|immediately dangerous to life and health]] value for fluorine.{{harvnb|Keplinger|Suissa|1968}}. Eyes and noses are seriously damaged at 100 ppm, and inhalation of 1,000 ppm fluorine will cause death in minutes,{{harvnb|Emsley|2011|p=179}}. compared to 270 ppm for hydrogen cyanide.{{harvnb|Biller|2007|p=939}}. {{clear}} {{Chembox | show_footer = no |Section7={{Chembox Hazards | ExternalSDS = | GHSPictograms = {{GHS03}}{{GHS05}}{{GHS06}}{{GHS08}} | GHSSignalWord = Danger | HPhrases = {{H-phrases|270|330|314|318}}https://www.airgas.com/msds/001061.pdf | NFPA-H = 4 | NFPA-F = 0 | NFPA-R = 4 | NFPA-S = W+OX | NFPA_ref = }} }} ===Hydrofluoric acid=== [[File:HF burned hands.jpg|thumb|alt=left and right hands, two views, burned index fingers|Hydrofluoric acid burns may not be evident for a day, after which calcium treatments are less effective.{{Harvnb|Eaton|1997}}.]] {{See also|Chemical burn}} Hydrofluoric acid is a contact poison with greater hazards than many strong acids like sulfuric acid even though it is weak: it remains neutral in aqueous solution and thus penetrates tissue faster, whether through inhalation, ingestion or the skin, and at least nine U.S. workers died in such accidents from 1984 to 1994. It reacts with calcium and magnesium in the blood leading to [[hypocalcemia]] and possible death through [[cardiac arrhythmia]].{{harvnb|Blodgett|Suruda|Crouch|2001}}. Insoluble calcium fluoride formation triggers strong pain{{Harvnb|Hoffman et al.|2007|p=1333}}. and burns larger than 160 cm2 (25 in2) can cause serious systemic toxicity.{{Harvnb|HSM|2006}}. Exposure may not be evident for eight hours for 50% HF, rising to 24 hours for lower concentrations, and a burn may initially be painless as hydrogen fluoride affects nerve function. If skin has been exposed to HF, damage can be reduced by rinsing it under a jet of water for 10–15 minutes and removing contaminated clothing.{{harvnb|Fischman|2001|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=PyUSgdZUGr4C&pg=PA458 458–459]}}. [[Calcium gluconate]] is often applied next, providing calcium ions to bind with fluoride; skin burns can be treated with 2.5% calcium gluconate gel or special rinsing solutions.{{harvnb|El Saadi et al.|1989}}.{{harvnb|Roblin et al.|2006}}.{{harvnb|Hultén et al.|2004}}. Hydrofluoric acid absorption requires further medical treatment; calcium gluconate may be injected or administered intravenously. Using calcium chloride – a common laboratory reagent – in lieu of calcium gluconate is contraindicated, and may lead to severe complications. Excision or amputation of affected parts may be required.{{Harvnb|Zorich|1991|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=sdB3KjhWzFQC&pg=PA183 182–183]}}. ===Fluoride ion=== {{See also|Fluoride toxicity}} Soluble fluorides are moderately toxic: 5–10 g sodium fluoride, or 32–64 mg fluoride ions per kilogram of body mass, represents a lethal dose for adults.{{Harvnb|Liteplo et al.|2002|p=100}}. One-fifth of the lethal dose can cause adverse health effects, and chronic excess consumption may lead to [[skeletal fluorosis]], which affects millions in Asia and Africa.{{harvnb|Reddy|2009}}. Ingested fluoride forms hydrofluoric acid in the stomach which is easily absorbed by the intestines, where it crosses cell membranes, binds with calcium and interferes with various enzymes, before urinary [[excretion]]. Exposure limits are determined by urine testing of the body's ability to clear fluoride ions.{{Harvnb|Shin|Silverberg|2013}}.{{harvnb|Baez|Baez|Marthaler|2000}}. Historically, most cases of fluoride poisoning have been caused by accidental ingestion of insecticides containing inorganic fluorides.{{Harvnb|Augenstein et al.|1991}}. Most current calls to poison control centers for possible fluoride poisoning come from the ingestion of fluoride-containing toothpaste. Malfunctioning water fluoridation equipment is another cause: one incident in Alaska affected almost 300 people and killed one person.{{harvnb|Gessner et al.|1994}}. Dangers from toothpaste are aggravated for small children, and the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] recommends supervising children below six brushing their teeth so that they do not swallow toothpaste.{{Harvnb|CDC|2013}}. One regional study examined a year of pre-teen fluoride poisoning reports totaling 87 cases, including one death from ingesting insecticide. Most had no symptoms, but about 30% had stomach pains. A larger study across the U.S. had similar findings: 80% of cases involved children under six, and there were few serious cases.{{Harvnb|Shulman|Wells|1997}}. ==Environmental concerns== ===Atmosphere=== [[File:Future ozone layer concentrations.gif|thumb|Animation|alt=Animation showing colored representation of ozone distribution by year above North America in 6 steps. It starts with a lot of ozone but by 2060 is all gone.|NASA projection of stratospheric ozone over North America without the Montreal Protocol{{Harvnb|Beck|Newman|Schindler|Perkins|2011}}.]] {{See also|Ozone depletion|global warming}} The [[Montreal Protocol]], signed in 1987, set strict regulations on chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and [[bromofluorocarbon]]s due to their ozone damaging potential (ODP). The high stability which suited them to their original applications also meant that they were not decomposing until they reached higher altitudes, where liberated chlorine and bromine atoms attacked ozone molecules.{{Harvnb|Aucamp|Björn|2010|pp=4–6, 41, 46–47}}. Even with the ban, and early indications of its efficacy, predictions warned that several generations would pass before full recovery.{{harvnb|Crow|2011}}.{{Harvnb|Barry|Phillips|2006}}. With one-tenth the ODP of CFCs, hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) are the current replacements,{{Harvnb|EPA|2013a}}. and are themselves scheduled for substitution by 2030–2040 by hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) with no chlorine and zero ODP.{{Harvnb|EPA|2013b}}. In 2007 this date was brought forward to 2020 for developed countries;{{harvnb|McCoy|2007}}. the [[Environmental Protection Agency]] had already prohibited one HCFC's production and capped those of two others in 2003. Fluorocarbon gases are generally [[greenhouse gas]]es with [[global-warming potential]]s (GWPs) of about 100 to 10,000; sulfur hexafluoride has a value of around 20,000.{{sfn|Forster et al.|2007|pp=212–213}} An outlier is [[HFO-1234yf]] which is a new type of refrigerant called a [[Hydrofluoroolefin]] (HFO) and has attracted global demand due to its GWP of 4 compared to 1,430 for the current refrigerant standard [[HFC-134a]]. ===Biopersistence=== [[File:PFOS-3D-vdW.png|[[Perfluorooctanesulfonic acid]], a key [[Scotchgard]] component until 2000{{sfn|Schwarcz|2004|p=37}}|thumb]] {{main|Biological aspects of fluorine#Biopersistence|l1=Biopersistence of fluorinated organics}} Organofluorines exhibit biopersistence due to the strength of the carbon–fluorine bond. [[Perfluoroalkyl acid]]s (PFAAs), which are sparingly water-soluble owing to their acidic functional groups, are noted [[persistent organic pollutant]]s;{{Harvnb|Giesy|Kannan|2002}}. [[perfluorooctanesulfonic acid]] (PFOS) and [[perfluorooctanoic acid]] (PFOA) are most often researched.{{Harvnb|EPA|2012}}. PFAAs have been found in trace quantities worldwide from polar bears to humans, with PFOS and PFOA known to reside in breast milk and the blood of newborn babies. A 2013 review showed a slight correlation between groundwater and soil PFAA levels and human activity; there was no clear pattern of one chemical dominating, and higher amounts of PFOS were correlated to higher amounts of PFOA.{{Harvnb|Zareitalabad|Siemens|Hamer|Amelung|2013}}. In the body, PFAAs bind to proteins such as [[serum albumin]]; they tend to concentrate within humans in the liver and blood before excretion through the kidneys. Dwell time in the body varies greatly by species, with half-lives of days in rodents, and years in humans.{{harvnb|Steenland|Fletcher|Savitz|2010}}.{{harvnb|Betts|2007}}.{{harvnb|Lau et al.|2007}}. High doses of PFOS and PFOA cause cancer and death in newborn rodents but human studies have not established an effect at current exposure levels. ==See also== * [[Fluoride selective electrode]], which measures fluoride concentration * [[Fluorine absorption dating]] * [[Fluorine-19 nuclear magnetic resonance|{{chem|19|F}} NMR]] * [[Fluorous chemistry]], a process used to separate reagents from [[organic solvents]] * [[Krypton fluoride laser|Krypton]] and [[argon fluoride laser]]s * [[Electrophilic fluorination|Electrophilic]] and [[radical fluorination|radical]] fluorination ==Notes== {{reflist|group="note"|30em}} ==Sources== === Citations === {{Reflist|21em}}{{bots|deny=Citation bot}} ===Indexed references=== {{Refbegin|35em|indent=yes}} :{{cite book|last1=Agricola|first1=Georgius|author1-link=Georgius Agricola|last2=Hoover|first2=Herbert Clark|last3=Hoover|first3=Lou Henry|date=1912|title=De Re Metallica|url=https://archive.org/stream/georgiusagricola00agririch#page/n5/mode/2up|location=London|publisher=The Mining Magazine|ref=harv}} :{{Cite book | last1 = Aigueperse | first1 = J.| last2 = Mollard | first2 = P.| last3 = Devilliers | first3 = D.| last4 = Chemla | first4 = M.| last5 = Faron | first5 = R.| last6 = Romano | first6 = R.
