'''Reprocessed uranium''' ('''RepU''') is the [[uranium]] recovered from [[nuclear reprocessing]], as done commercially in France, the UK and Japan and by [[List of states with nuclear weapons|nuclear weapons states]]' military plutonium production programs. This uranium actually makes up the bulk of the material separated during reprocessing. Commercial [[LWR]] [[spent nuclear fuel]] contains on average (excluding [[Cladding (nuclear fuel)|cladding]]) only four percent [[plutonium]], [[minor actinides]] and [[fission products]] by weight. Reuse of reprocessed uranium has not been common because of low prices in the [[uranium market]] of recent decades, and because it contains undesirable [[isotopes of uranium]]. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+Isotopic composition of reprocessed uranium{{cite web|url=http://world-nuclear.org/info/inf69.html|title=Processing of Used Nuclear Fuel|accessdate=2014-02-16|date=2013|publisher=World Nuclear Association}} !Isotope!!Proportion!!Characteristics |- |[[uranium-238]]||98.5%||[[Fertile material]] |- |[[uranium-237]]||0%||Around 0.001% at discharge, but half-life only 1 week.
Produces soluble, long-lived [[neptunium-237]] which is hard
to contain in a [[geological repository]]. |- |[[uranium-236]]||0.4%-0.6%||Neither fissile nor fertile. Affects reactivity. |- |[[uranium-235]]||0.5%-1.0%||[[Fissile material]] |- |[[uranium-234]]||>0.02%||[[Fertile material]] but can affect reactivity differently {{cite web|url=http://www.francenuc.org/en_mat/uranium4_e.htm|title=Uranium from reprocessing|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019023302/http://francenuc.org/en_mat/uranium4_e.htm|archivedate=2007-10-19|df=}} |- |[[uranium-233]]||trace||Fissile material |- |[[uranium-232]]||trace||Decay product [[thallium-208]] emits strong [[gamma radiation]] making handling difficult |} Given sufficiently high uranium prices, it is feasible for reprocessed uranium to be re-[[enriched uranium|enriched]] and reused. A higher enrichment level is required to compensate for the 236U which is lighter than 238U and therefore concentrates in the enriched product.{{cite web |url=http://www.inl.gov/technicalpublications/Documents/3667084.pdf |title=Advanced Fuel Cycle Cost Basis |publisher=Idaho National Laboratory |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://swap.stanford.edu/20090124231050/http://www.inl.gov/technicalpublications/Documents/3667084.pdf |archivedate=2009-01-24 |df= }} Also, if [[Breeder_reactor#Fast_breeder_reactor|fast breeder reactors]] ever come into commercial use, reprocessed uranium, like [[depleted uranium]], will be usable in their breeding blankets. There have been some studies involving the use of reprocessed uranium in [[CANDU]] reactors. CANDU is designed to use natural uranium as fuel; the U-235 content remaining in spent PWR/BWR fuel is typically greater than that found in natural uranium, which is about 0.72% U-235, allowing the re-enrichment step to be skipped. Fuel cycle tests also have included the DUPIC (Direct Use of spent PWR fuel In CANDU) fuel cycle, where used fuel from a Pressurized Water Reactor (PWR) is packaged into a CANDU fuel bundle with only physical reprocessing (cut into pieces) but no chemical reprocessing.{{cite web|url=http://www.nuclearfaq.ca/brat_fuel.htm |website=DUPIC| title=The Evolution of CANDU Fuel Cycles and Their Potential Contribution to World Peace}} ==References== [https://swap.stanford.edu/20090124231050/http://www.inl.gov/technicalpublications/Documents/3667084.pdf Advanced Fuel Cycle Cost Basis - Idaho National Laboratory] *Module K2 '''Aqueously Reprocessed Uranium Conversion and Disposition''' *Module K3 '''Pyrochemically/Pyrometallurgically Reprocessed Uranium Conversion and Disposition''' {{Nuclear Technology}} [[Category:Nuclear materials]] [[Category:Nuclear reprocessing]] [[Category:Uranium]]

[[File:Oak Park Boulevard.jpg|thumb|300px|A "parkway" with [[street trees]] in [[Oak Park, Illinois]]]] A '''road verge''' is a strip of grass or plants, and sometimes also [[tree]]s, located between a [[roadway]] (carriageway) and a [[sidewalk]] (pavement). Verges are known by dozens of other names, often quite regional; see [[#Terminology|Terminology]], below. The land is often [[public property]], with maintenance usually being a municipal responsibility. Some municipal authorities, however, require that abutting property owners maintain their respective verge areas, as well as the adjunct [[footpath]]s or [[sidewalk]]s.{{cite web|url=https://www.fhwa.dot.gov/environment/bicycle_pedestrian/publications/sidewalk2/sidewalks210.cfm |title=Designing Sidewalks and Trails for Access, Part II of II: Best Practices Design Guide, Section 10.1.3: Maintenance responsibilities| date = 25 September 2017 | work = Bicycle and Pedestrian Program |publisher=Federal Highways Administration, U.S. Department of Transportation | accessdate= 10 March 2018}} Benefits include visual aesthetics, increased safety and comfort of sidewalk users, protection from spray from passing vehicles, and a space for benches, [[bus shelter]]s, street lights, and other public amenities. Verges are also often part of [[sustainability]] for [[water conservation]] or the management of [[urban runoff]] and [[water pollution]]{{cite web | url = http://www.rainwatercollecting.com/blog/?p=448 | title = Passive Rainwater Harvesting | accessdate = 7 July 2010 | date = 19 September 2009 | first = Jeremy | last = Delost | work = The Rainwater Observer | dead-url = yes | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20091223200107/http://www.rainwatercollecting.com/blog/?p=448 | archive-date = 23 December 2009 | df = }}{{citation |url=http://www.smgov.net/uploadedFiles/Departments/OSE/Categories/Landscape/PLP%2005.27.09.pdf | format = PDF | title = Parkway Landscaping Policy for the City of Santa Monica | date = 1 February 2010 | publisher = City of [[Santa Monica, California]] |accessdate= 7 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612182146/http://smgov.net/uploadedFiles/Departments/OSE/Categories/Landscape/PLP%2005.27.09.pdf |archivedate=12 June 2010 |df=}}{{cite journal |url=http://www.enewsbuilder.net/watercon/e_article000771115.cfm?x=bbrDcbK,b2FRwTrq,w |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722043546/http://www.enewsbuilder.net/watercon/e_article000771115.cfm?x=bbrDcbK,b2FRwTrq,w | archive-date = 22 July 2011 |title=Pruning the Parkway Strip | journal = WaterWise | volume = 4 | number = 3 | date = 14 March 2007 | publisher = Austin Water, City of Austin Water Conservation | location = [[Austin, Texas]] |accessdate= 7 July 2010}} and can provide useful wildlife habitat. Snow that has been ploughed off the street in colder climates often is stored in the area of the verge by default.{{fact|date=March 2016}} In the [[British Isles]], verges are the last location of habitats for a range of [[flora]].{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-33029385 | title = Roadside verges 'last refuge for wild flowers' | work = BBC News | publisher = [[BBC]] | last = Briggs | first = Helen | date = 6 June 2015 | accessdate = 6 June 2015}} [[File:Roadside Verge.jpg|thumb|Protection of roadside verge in Northumberland UK]] The main disadvantage of a road verge is that the right-of-way must be wider, increasing the cost of the road. In some localities, a wider verge offers opportunity for later road widening, should the traffic usage of a road demand this. For this reason, footpaths are usually sited a significant distance from the curb.{{fact|date=March 2016}} == Terminology == The term ''verge'' has many [[synonym]]s and [[dialect]]al differences. Some [[dialect]]s and [[idiolect]]s lack a specific term for this area, instead using a [[circumlocution]].{{cite news|url=https://www.the-tls.co.uk/articles/private/the-triumph-of-slang/ |title=The triumph of slang| first = John A. needed|date=December 2016}} ==Sustainable urban and landscape design== [[File:Treelawn2.JPG|thumb|300px|Planted [[rain garden]] in the "tree lawn" zone]] In urban and suburban areas, [[urban runoff]] from private and civic properties can be guided by [[grading (engineering)|grading]] and [[bioswale]]s for [[rainwater harvesting]] collection and [[bioretention]] within the "tree-lawn" - parkway zone in [[rain garden]]s. This is done for reducing runoff of rain and domestic water: for their carrying waterborne pollution off-site into [[storm drain]]s and sewer systems; and for the [[groundwater recharge]] of [[aquifer]]s. In some cities, such as [[Santa Monica, California]], city code mandates specify:
Parkways, the area between the outside edge of the sidewalk and the inside edge of the curb which are a component of the Public Right of Way (PROW) - that the landscaping should require little or no irrigation and the area produce no runoff.
For Santa Monica, another reason for this use of "tree-lawns" is to reduce current beach and [[Santa Monica Bay]] ocean pollution that is measurably higher at city outfalls. New construction and remodeling projects needing [[building permit]]s require that [[landscape design]] submittals include [[garden design]] plans showing the means of compliance. In some cities and counties, such as [[Portland, Oregon]], street and highway departments are regrading and planting [[rain garden]]s in road verges to reduce boulevard and highway runoff. This practice can be useful in areas with either independent [[Storm drain|Storm sewers]] or [[combined sewers|combined storm and sanitary sewers]], reducing the frequency of pollution, treatment costs, and released overflows of untreated sewage into rivers and oceans during rainstorms.{{cite web|url=http://www.portlandonline.com/BES/index.cfm?c=34598|title=Sustainable Stormwater Management|accessdate=2010-04-28}} ==Rural roadsides== In some countries, the road verge can be a corridor of vegetation that remains after adjacent land has been cleared. Considerable effort in supporting conservation of the remnant vegetation is prevalent in Australia, where significant tracts of land are managed as part of the ''roadside conservation'' strategies by government agencies.{{Citation | author1=Western Australia. Roadside Conservation Committee | title=Roadsides -- the vital link : a decade of roadside conservation in Western Australia (1985-1995) | publication-date=1995 | publisher=Roadside Conservation Committee | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/23235561 | accessdate=2012-04-14 }} ==Gallery== File:Ginkgo Riverside, Illinois.JPG|[[Ginkgo]] street trees in the "boulevard" area, in [[Riverside, Illinois]] File:Treelawn1.JPG|A planted [[garden]] in the "tree lawn", in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]] File:Massachusetts-devils strip.JPG|A curb strip in suburban [[Greater Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]. Outside of rural areas in New England, devil strips are narrow - the one pictured is {{convert|52|in|cm m}} from curb to sidewalk. They are usually not maintained by the municipality, but rather by the property owner, and are used primarily to provide space for utility poles. ==See also== *[[Central reservation]] *[[Roadside conservation]] *[[Shoulder (road)]] *[[Urban forestry]] *[[Long acre (road verge)|Long acre]] - a traditional term for wide grassy road verges, used by grazed by herds or flocks moving from place to place *[[:Category:Environmental conservation]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wiktionary}} * [http://www.fcgov.com/horticulture/infernogarden.php Parkway with [[xeriscape|xeric garden]] photographs] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090221085936/http://www.mrexcel.com/devilstrip.html Devil Strips] – term's use and lore {{Road types}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Road verge}} [[Category:Urban studies and planning terminology]] [[Category:Hydrology and urban planning]] [[Category:Environmental design]] [[Category:Water conservation]] [[Category:Types of garden]]

[[File:Robotic Refueling Mission.ogv|thumb|350px|Video of the Robotic Refueling Mission.]] [[File:STS 135 RRM installed on the LMC.jpg|thumbnail|350px|Robotic Refueling Mission (RRM) installed on its Support Structure Carrier. The RRM flew aboard [[Space Shuttle Atlantis]] on the [[STS-135]] mission]] The '''Robotic Refueling Mission''' (RRM) is a [[NASA]] technology demonstration mission with equipment launches in both 2011 and 2013 to increase the technological maturity of [[outer space|in-space]] [[rocket propellant]] [[propellant transfer|transfer]] technology by testing a wide variety of potential propellant transfer hardware, of both new and existing [[satellite]] designs.
The first phase of the mission was successfully completed in 2013. The second phase experiments continued in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://phys.org/news/2015-07-nasa-robotic-onboard-space-station.html|title = NASA robotic servicing demonstrations continue onboard the space station|website = phys.org|access-date = 2016-03-03}}</ref>
==History==
===Development=== The Robotic Refueling Mission was developed by the Satellite Servicing Capabilities Office at the [[Goddard Space Flight Center]] (GSFC).<ref name=nasa20110805> {{cite web |title=Robotic Refueling Mission (RRM) |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/experiments/RRM.html|publisher=[[NASA]]|accessdate=5 August 2011}}</ref> It was planned to demonstrate the technology and tools to [[propellant transfer|refuel]] [[satellite]]s in orbit by robotic means.<ref name=sn20100402> {{cite web |url=http://www.spacenews.com/civil/100402-nasa-plans-refuel-mock-satellite.html |title=NASA Plans To Refuel Mock Satellite at the Space Station |author=Debra Werner |publisher=Space News |date=2 April 2010 |accessdate=10 March 2011 }}</ref> After the proof of concept, the long-term goal of NASA is to transfer the technology to the commercial sector.<ref name=sn20100402/>
RRM was designed with four tools, each with electronics and two cameras and lights. Additionally, it had pumps and controllers and electrical systems such as electrical valves and sensors.<ref name=cheung2011> {{cite web |url=http://www.edcheung.com/job/iss/iss.html|title=Satellite Servicing Demonstration |author=Ed Cheung |publisher=edcheung.com |accessdate=10 March 2011 }}</ref>
The RRM payload was transported to the [[Kennedy Space Center]] in early March 2011, where the GSFC team performed the final preparations for space flight.<ref>{{cite web|title=Satellite Servicing Capabilities Office Newsroom|url=https://ssco.gsfc.nasa.gov/newsroom.html|website=National Aeronautic and Space Administration|accessdate=28 September 2016}}</ref> Once up on the International Space Station, RRM was planned to be installed into the ELC-4.{{clarify|date=January 2013}} The [[Dextre]] robot was planned to be used in 2012 and 2013 during the refueling demonstration experiments.<ref name=nasa20110816> {{cite news |title=Robotic Refueling Module, Soon To Be Relocated to Permanent Space Station Position |url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/goddard/news/features/2011/rrm-issposition.html |accessdate=18 August 2011 |newspaper=NASA website |date=16 August 2011}}</ref>
===Launch=== The RRM phase 1 experiment platform was launched to the [[International Space Station]] (ISS) on 8 July 2011, transported by [[Space Shuttle]] ''[[Space Shuttle Atlantis|Atlantis]]'' on [[STS-135]], the 135th and final flight mission of the [[Federal Government of the United States|American]] Space Shuttle program.<ref name=nasa20110805/><ref name="approved">{{cite web| url = http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2010/08/nasa-approve-sts-135-mission-june-28-2011-launch/ | title = NASA managers approve STS-135 mission planning for June 28, 2011 launch| accessdate= 20 August 2010| publisher= NASA Space flight |first=Chris|last=Bergin}}</ref><ref name= signed>{{cite news|title= Obama signs Nasa up to new future| url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-11518049|newspaper=BBC|date=11 October 2010}}</ref>
==Technology demonstration==
===Phase 1=== NASA successfully completed the phase 1 demonstration mission in January 2013, performing a series of [[robotic]] [[Liquid rocket propellants|refuelings]] of satellite hardware that had not been designed for refueling . An extensive series of [[robotics|robotically-actuated]] [[propellant transfer]] experiments on the exposed facility platform of the [[International Space Station]] (ISS) were completed by the RRM equipment suite and the [[Canadarm]]/[[Dextre]] robotic arm combination.<ref name=sfn20130125> {{cite news |last=Clark|first=Stephen |title=Satellite refueling testbed completes demo in orbit |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/news/n1301/25rrm/#.UQQMpvJ5GIR |accessdate=2013-01-26 |newspaper=Spaceflight Now |date=2013-01-25}}</ref>
The experiment suite included a number of [[rocket propellant|propellant]] [[valve]]s, [[nozzle]]s and [[Seal (mechanical)|seals]] similar to those used on a wide variety [[Communications satellite|commercial]] and [[Federal government of the United States|U.S. government]] satellites, plus a series of four [[prototype]] [[Robot end effector|tools]] that could be attached to the [[distal]] end of the Dextre [[robotic arm]]. Each tool was a prototype of a device that could be used by future satellite servicing missions to refuel spacecraft in orbit. RRM is the first in-space refueling demonstration using a platform of fuel valves and spacecraft plumbing representative of most existing satellites, which were not designed for refueling.<ref name=sfn20130125/>
===Phase 2=== Phase 2 of the RRM mission began in August 2013 with the launch of the phase 2 RRM hardware to the ISS aboard the Japanese [[H-II Transfer Vehicle]] 4 ([[HTV-4]]) for test operations expected to be carried out in 2014.<ref name=pa20130804> {{cite news |last=Messier|first=Doug |title=Robotic Refueling Mission Gears Up for Phase 2 |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2013/08/04/robotic-refueling-mission-gears-up-for-phase-2/ |accessdate=2013-08-05 |newspaper=Parabolic Arc |date=2013-08-04 }}</ref>
The Phase 2 hardware complement consists of:<ref name=pa20130804/> *Two additional RRM task boards *The RRM On-orbit Transfer Cage *The [[Visual Inspection Poseable Invertebrate Robot]] (VIPIR)—a "borescope inspection tool that provides a set of eyes for internal satellite repair jobs." It was launched on ATV-5 and arrived at the station on August 2014 <ref name=VIPIRarrives>{{NASA’s Space Station Fix-It Demo for Satellites Gets Hardware for 2.0 Update|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/news/rrm_update/#.U-o_jCQcB9U}}</ref>
In February 2014 the ground-based 'Remote Robotic Oxidizer Transfer Test' (RROxiTT) transferred [[nitrogen tetroxide]] (NTO) via a standard satellite-fueling valve at the satellite fuelling facility, [[Kennedy Space Center]] (KSC), using a robot [[teleoperation|controlled remotely]] from the [[Goddard Space Flight Centre]], {{convert|800|mi}} away in [[Greenbelt, Maryland]].<ref name=av-wk-transfer>{{cite web |author=Morring, Frank, Jr. |url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/awx_02_28_2014_p0-667874.xml |title=NASA Robotically Transfers Satellite Oxidizer |publisher=Aviationweek.com |date=February 28, 2014 |accessdate=April 5, 2014}}</ref>
On March 26, 2015 The RRM On-orbit Transfer Cage was loaded into the Kibo airlock and picked up by the JEM Robotic Arm who handed it off to Dextre for installation on the main module.
On April 30, 2015 The RRM On-Orbit Transfer Cage was installed on the main module and the Phase 1 hardware was removed and placed in the cage for disposal on HTV-4. The experiment was then activated that same day.
February 2016 the Phase 2 experiment was deactivated and all fuel and cooling lines were turned off in preparation for disposal of the RRM payload and its fuel on SpaceX Dragon CRS-10.
On February 23, 2017 The main module of the RRM experiment and the Phase 2 hardware were removed and stored in the trunk of [[SpaceX CRS-10]] for disposal and the STP H5 experiment with Raven was activated beginning Phase 3.
=== Phase 3 === With the completion of Phase 2 Phase 3 testing is underway with the launch of Raven on CRS-10. The new Phase 3 module will be delivered to the station in December 2018 on [[SpaceX CRS-16]].
==See also== *[[Advanced Cryogenic Evolved Stage]] *[[Orbital Express]] *[[Propellant depot]] *[[Space Infrastructure Servicing]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_5XOoqxb6g8#! ISS Update: Robotic Refueling Mission Payload Overview], NASA video, January 25, 2013. "it is, or it might be—only history will tell—the start of what could be a revolution or a new era of how satellites are built and flown in space"
{{Use American English|date=January 2014}}

A '''rotating detonation engine''' ('''RDE''') is a proposed engine using a form of pressure gain combustion, where one or more detonations continuously travel around an annular channel. Although none are in production, computational simulations and experimental results have shown that the RDE has potential,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Lu |first=Frank |last2=Braun |first2=Eric |date=7 July 2014 |title=Rotating Detonation Wave Propulsion: Experimental Challenges, Modeling, and Engine Concepts |url=http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/1.B34802 |journal=Journal of Propulsion and Power |publisher=The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics |volume=30 |issue=5 |pages=1125–1142 |doi=10.2514/1.B34802}}</ref> and there is wide interest and research into the concept.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wolanski|first1=Piotr|title=Detonative Propulsion|journal=Proceedings of the Combustion Institute|date=2013|volume=34|issue=1|pages=125-158|doi=10.1016/j.proci.2012.10.005}}</ref>
Theoretically, detonative combustion, (i.e. that which happens at speeds above the speeds of sound), is more efficient than the conventional [[Deflagration|deflagrative combustion]] by as much as 25%<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://rg.ru/2018/01/18/levochkin-vozmozhnost-sozdaniia-detonacionnogo-dvigatelia-podtverdilas.html|title=В России испытали модель детонационного двигателя для ракет будущего|date=2018-01-18|work=Российская газета|access-date=2018-02-10}}</ref>. If this theoretical gain in efficiency can be realized, there would be a major fuel savings benefit.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cao|first1=Huan|last2=Wilson|first2=Donald|title=Parametric Cycle Analysis of Continuous Rotating Detonation Ejector-Augmented Rocket Engine|journal=49th AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE Joint Propulsion Conference|date=14–17 July 2013|page=AIAA 2013-3971|doi=10.2514/6.2013-3971|url=http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/6.2013-3971}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Schwer |first=Douglas |last2=Kailasanath |first2=Kailas |date=25 September 2010 |title=Numerical Investigation of the Physics of Rotating Detonation Engines |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1540748910003159 |journal=Proceedings of the Combustion Institute |publisher=Elsevier, Inc. |volume=33 |issue=2 |pages=2195–2202 |doi=10.1016/j.proci.2010.07.050}}</ref> Because the combustion is supersonic, it can also more efficiently provide thrust at speeds above the speed of sound.
The disadvantages of the RDE include stability and noise.
== How it works == The basic concept of an RDE is a detonation wave that travels around an annulus, which is a circular channel. First, fuel and oxidizer are injected into the channel, normally through small holes or slits. Initially, a detonation must be initiated in the fuel/oxidizer mixture by use of some form of ignitor. After the engine is started, however, the detonation is self-sustaining. The passing detonation ignites the fuel/oxidizer mixture, which releases the energy necessary to sustain the detonation. The combustion products expand out of the channel and are also pushed out of the channel by the incoming fuel and oxidizer.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wolanski|first1=Piotr|title=Detonative Propulsion|journal=Proceedings of the Combustion Institute|date=2013|volume=34|issue=1|pages=125-158|doi=10.1016/j.proci.2012.10.005}}</ref>
Although the RDE's design is similar to the [[Pulse detonation engine|pulse detonation engine (PDE)]], one aspect that makes the RDE superior is the fact that the waves constantly cycle around the chamber, while the PDE requires the chambers to be purged after each pulse.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Pressure Gain Combustion Program Committee - Resources |url = https://info.aiaa.org/tac/pc/PGCPC/Resources/Resources.aspx |website = AIAA Pressure Gain Combustion Program Committee |accessdate = 2016-12-30}}</ref>
An image of an RDE can be found on the [https://info.aiaa.org/tac/pc/PGCPC/Resources/Resources.aspx American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Pressure Gain Combustion Program Committee's Resources page].
== Current development == Several organisations have been working on RDE design.
=== US Navy=== The [[US Navy]] is pushing the development of this engine,<ref>{{Cite web|title = How the Rotating Detonation Engine Works|url = http://auto.howstuffworks.com/under-the-hood/trends-innovations/rotating-detonation-engine3.htm|website = HowStuffWorks|accessdate = 2015-11-09}}</ref> but there is no known time of completion. Researchers at the [[United States Naval Research Laboratory|Naval Research Laboratory (NRL)]] have been showing particular interest in detonation engines, such as the RDE, because they realize these engines have the capability to reduce the fuel consumption in their heavy vehicles.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = US Navy developing rotating detonation engine|url = http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/magazine/physicstoday/news/news-picks/usnvydevelopingrottingdetontionengine-a-news-pick-post|journal = Physics Today|date = 2012-11-06|issn = 0031-9228|doi=10.1063/PT.5.026505}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = How the Rotating Detonation Engine Works|url = http://auto.howstuffworks.com/under-the-hood/trends-innovations/rotating-detonation-engine2.htm|website = HowStuffWorks|accessdate = 2015-10-21}}</ref> Several obstacles still remain to overcome in order to use the RDE in the field.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Navy Researchers Look to Rotating Detonation Engines to Power the Future - U.S. Naval Research Laboratory|url = http://www.nrl.navy.mil/media/news-releases/2012/Navy-Researchers-Look-to-Rotating-Detonation-Engines-to-Power-the-Future|website = www.nrl.navy.mil|accessdate = 2015-11-09}}</ref> NRL researchers are currently focusing on getting a better understanding of how the RDE works.
=== Aerojet Rocketdyne === Since 2010, [[Aerojet Rocketdyne]] has conducted over 520 tests of multiple configurations of a rotating detonation engine.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Claflin|first1=Scott|title=Recent Advances in Power Cycles Using Rotating Detonation Engines with Subcritical and Supercritical CO2|url=http://www.swri.org/4org/d18/sCO2/papers2014/systemConcepts/09PPT-Claflin.pdf|website=Southwest Research Institute|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref>
=== NASA === Researchers at [[NASA]] also play a part in the development of the RDE. [http://www.grc.nasa.gov/WWW/cdtb/personnel/dan.html Daniel Paxson], an accredited scientist at the [[Glenn Research Center]], has used simulations in [[Computational fluid dynamics|computational fluid dynamics (CFD)]] to assess the RDE's detonation frame of reference and compares the performance with the PDE.<ref>{{Cite web|title = UCSB Full Bib - External Link|url = http://pegasus.library.ucsb.edu/F/MBE5776HMPFJMQ45D8TAUSM6V9237AU4DVN1D521M49XLCE8CG-35036?func=service&doc_library=SBA01&doc_number=004533761&line_number=0001&func_code=WEB-FULL&service_type=MEDIA|website = pegasus.library.ucsb.edu|accessdate = 2015-11-09}}</ref> He found that the results from his code of the RDE were shown to be in favor of those from a more complex code; thus, stating that the RDE can perform at least on the same level. Furthermore, he found that the performance of the RDE can be directly compared to the PDE as their performance were essentially the same.
=== Energomash === According to the Russian Vice Prime Minister [[Dmitry Rogozin]],<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/dmitry.rogozin/posts/1651863201503679?pnref=story Facebook post], in Russian</ref> in mid-January 2018 [[NPO Energomash]] company successfully completed the initial test phase of the 2-ton class [[liquid-propellant rocket|liquid propelant]] RDE and plans to develop larger ones for use in the space launch vehicles.
===Other research=== Other experiments have used numerical procedures to better understand the flow-field of the RDE.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Numerical investigation of the physics of rotating-detonation-engines|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1540748910003159|journal = Proceedings of the Combustion Institute|date = 2011-01-01|pages = 2195–2202|volume = 33|issue = 2|doi = 10.1016/j.proci.2010.07.050|first = Douglas|last = Schwer|first2 = Kailas|last2 = Kailasanath}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EBcflqPNhCY Video Demonstrating how the RDE Works] * [http://permanent.access.gpo.gov/gpo57039/20140013391.pdf Daniel Paxson's Research Paper on his findings of the RDE]

[[Image:Carbon dioxide pressure-temperature phase diagram.svg|thumb|Carbon dioxide pressure-temperature phase diagram]]
'''Supercritical carbon dioxide''' ('''s{{chem|CO|2}}''') is a fluid state of [[carbon dioxide]] where it is held at or above its [[critical temperature]] and [[critical pressure]].
Carbon dioxide usually behaves as a [[gas]] in [[air]] at [[Standard conditions for temperature and pressure|standard temperature and pressure]] (STP), or as a [[solid]] called [[dry ice]] when frozen. If the [[temperature]] and [[pressure]] are both increased from STP to be at or above the [[Critical point (thermodynamics)|critical point]] for carbon dioxide, it can adopt properties midway between a gas and a [[liquid]]. More specifically, it behaves as a [[supercritical fluid]] above its critical temperature ({{convert|304.25|K|C F|abbr=on|disp=comma}}) and critical pressure ({{convert|72.9|atm|MPa psi bar|abbr=on|disp=comma}}), expanding to fill its container like a gas but with a [[density]] like that of a liquid.
Supercritical {{chem|CO|2}} is becoming an important commercial and industrial [[solvent]] due to its role in chemical [[extraction (chemistry)|extraction]] in addition to its low toxicity and environmental impact. The relatively low temperature of the process and the stability of {{chem|CO|2}} also allows most compounds to be extracted with little damage or [[Denaturation_(biochemistry)|denaturing]]. In addition, the solubility of many extracted compounds in {{chem|CO|2}} varies with pressure,<ref>Discovery - Can Chemistry Save The World? - BBC World Service</ref> permitting selective extractions.
==Applications==
===Solvent=== {{Main|Supercritical fluid extraction}} Carbon dioxide is gaining popularity among [[coffee]] manufacturers looking to move away from classic decaffeinating [[solvent]]s, because of real or perceived dangers related to their use in food preparation. s{{chem|CO|2}} is forced through the green coffee beans which are then sprayed with water at high pressure to remove the caffeine. The caffeine can then be isolated for resale (e.g. to the pharmaceutical or beverage manufacturers) by passing the water through [[activated carbon|activated charcoal filters]] or by [[distillation]], [[crystallization]] or [[reverse osmosis]]. Supercritical carbon dioxide is used to remove [[organochloride]] pesticides and metals from agricultural crops without adulterating the desired constituents from the plant matter in the herbal supplement industry.<ref>Department of Pharmaceutical Analysis, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University, Shenyang 110016, China</ref>
Supercritical carbon dioxide can be used as a more environmentally friendly solvent for [[dry cleaning]] over traditional solvents such as hydrocarbons, including [[perchloroethylene]].<ref>{{citation |first=Gina|last=Stewart |title=Dry Cleaning with Liquid Carbon Dioxide|journal=Green chemistry using liquid and s{{chem|CO|2}} |editors=Joseph M. DeSimone and William Tumas |year=2003 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=United States |pages=215–227}}</ref>
Supercritical carbon dioxide is used as the extraction solvent for creation of [[essential oils]] and other [[herbal distillates]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Aizpurua-Olaizola|first=Oier|last2=Ormazabal|first2=Markel|last3=Vallejo|first3=Asier|last4=Olivares|first4=Maitane|last5=Navarro|first5=Patricia|last6=Etxebarria|first6=Nestor|last7=Usobiaga|first7=Aresatz|date=2015-01-01|title=Optimization of supercritical fluid consecutive extractions of fatty acids and polyphenols from Vitis vinifera grape wastes|journal=Journal of Food Science|volume=80|issue=1|pages=E101–107|doi=10.1111/1750-3841.12715|issn=1750-3841|pmid=25471637}}</ref> Its main advantages over solvents such as [[hexane]] and [[acetone]] in this process are that it is non-toxic and non-flammable. Furthermore, separation of the reaction components from the starting material is much simpler than with traditional [[organic solvents]]. The {{chem|CO|2}} can evaporate into the air or be recycled by condensation into a cold recovery vessel. Its advantage over [[steam distillation]] is that it operates at a lower temperature, which can separate the plant [[waxes]] from the oils.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 =Mendiola | first1 =J.A. | last2 =Herrero | first2 =M. | last3 =Cifuentes | first3 =A. | last4 =Ibañez | first4 =E. | year =2007 | title =Use of compressed fluids for sample preparation: Food applications | url =| journal =Journal of Chromatography A | volume =1152 | issue =1-2| pages =234–246 | doi =10.1016/j.chroma.2007.02.046 }}</ref>
In [[laboratory|laboratories]], s{{chem|CO|2}} is used as an extraction solvent, for example for determining total recoverable hydrocarbons from soils, sediments, fly-ash and other media,<ref>[https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20081217144727/http://www.epa.gov/epawaste/hazard/testmethods/index.htm U.S.EPA Method 3560 Supercritical Fluid Extraction of Total Recoverable Hydrocarbons]</ref> and determination of [[polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons]] in soil and solid wastes.<ref>[http://www.epa.gov/SW-846/pdfs/3561.pdf U.S.EPA Method 3561 Supercritical Fluid Extraction of Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons].</ref> Supercritical fluid extraction has been used in determining [[hydrocarbon]] components in water.<ref>[http://norden.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2:796602/FULLTEXT01.pdf Use of Ozone Depleting Substances in Laboratories]. TemaNord 2003:516.</ref>
Processes that use s{{chem|CO|2}} to produce micro and [[Nano-|nano]] scale particles, often for [[pharmaceutical]] uses, are under development. The gas [[antisolvent]] process, rapid expansion of supercritical solutions and supercritical antisolvent [[precipitation (chemistry)|precipitation]] (as well as several related methods) process a variety of substances into particles.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 =Yeo | first1 =S. | last2 =Kiran | first2 =E. | year =2005 | title =Formation of polymer particles with supercritical fluids: A review | doi =10.1016/j.supflu.2004.10.006 | journal =J. Supercrit. Fluids | volume =34 | issue =| pages =287–308 }}</ref>
Due to its ability to selectively dissolve organic compounds and assist the functioning of enzymes, s{{chem|CO|2}} has been suggested as a potential solvent to support biological activity on [[Venus]]- or [[super-Earth]]-type planets.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Budisa|first1=Nediljko|last2=Schulze-Makuch|first2=Dirk|title=Supercritical Carbon Dioxide and Its Potential as a Life-Sustaining Solvent in a Planetary Environment|journal=Life|date=8 August 2014|volume=4|issue=3|pages=331–340|url=http://www.mdpi.com/2075-1729/4/3/331|doi=10.3390/life4030331}}</ref>
===Manufactured products=== Environmentally beneficial, low-cost substitutes for rigid [[thermoplastic]] and fired [[ceramic]] are made using s{{chem|CO|2}} as a [[chemical reagent]]. The s{{chem|CO|2}} in these processes is reacted with the alkaline components of fully hardened [[hydraulic cement]] or [[gypsum]] [[plaster]] to form various carbonates.<ref>{{citation |first=James B.|last=Rubin |first2=Craig M. V. |last2=Taylor |first3=Thomas |last3=Hartmann |first4=Patricia |last4=Paviet-Hartmann |title=Enhancing the Properties of Portland Cements Using Supercritical Carbon Dioxide|journal=Green chemistry using liquid and supercritical carbon dioxide |editors=Joseph M. DeSimone and William Tumas |year=2003 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=USA |pages=241–255}}</ref> The primary byproduct is water.
Supercritical carbon dioxide is used in the foaming of [[polymers]]. Supercritical carbon dioxide can saturate the polymer with solvent. Upon depressurization and heating the carbon dioxide rapidly expands, causing voids within the polymer matrix, i.e., creating a foam. Research is also ongoing at many universities in the production of microcellular foams using s{{chem|CO|2}}.
An [[electrosynthesis|electrochemical]] [[carboxylation]] of a para-[[isobutyl]][[benzyl chloride]] to [[ibuprofen]] is promoted under s{{chem|CO|2}}.<ref name=SCY>{{cite journal | last1 =Sakakura | first1 =Toshiyasu | author1-link =Toshiyasu Sakakura | last2 =Choi | first2 =Jun-Chul | author2-link =Jun-Chul Choi | last3 =Yasuda | first3 =Hiroyuki | author3-link =Hiroyuki Yasuda | title =Transformation of Carbon dioxide | journal =Chemical Reviews | volume =107 | issue =6 | pages =2365–2387 | publisher =American Chemical Society | location =| date =13 June 2007 | url =http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/cr068357u | issn = | doi =10.1021/cr068357u | mr = | zbl =| pmid=17564481}}</ref>
===Working fluid=== Supercritical {{chem|CO|2}} is chemically stable, reliable, low-cost, non-toxic, non-flammable and readily available, making it a desirable candidate working fluid.
====Power generation ==== The unique properties of s{{chem|CO|2}} present advantages for closed-loop power generation and can be applied to various power generation applications. Power generation systems that use traditional air [[Brayton cycle|Brayton]] and steam [[Rankine cycle]]s can be upgraded to s{{chem|CO|2}} to increase efficiency and power output.
The relatively new [[Allam power cycle]] uses sCO2 as the working fluid in combination with fuel and pure oxygen. The CO2 produced by combustion mixes with the sCO2 working fluid and a corresponding amount of pure CO2 must be removed from the process (for industrial use or sequestration). This process reduces atmospheric emissions to zero.
It presents interesting properties that promise substantial improvements in system efficiency. Due to its high fluid density, s{{chem|CO|2}} enables extremely compact and highly efficient turbomachinery. It can use simpler, single casing body designs while [[steam turbine]]s require multiple turbine stages and associated casings, as well as additional inlet and outlet piping. The high density allows for highly compact, microchannel-based heat exchanger technology.<ref>{{Cite web|url =http://www.echogen.com/documents/why-sco2-can-displace-steam.pdf|title =Supercritical CO2 Power Cycle Developments and Commercialization: Why sCO2 can Displace Steam|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =|last =|first =}}</ref>
In 2016, General Electric announced an s{{chem|CO|2}}-based turbine that operated at 50% efficiency. In it the {{chem|CO|2}} is heated to 700 °C. It requires less compression and allows heat transfer. It reaches full power in 2 minutes, whereas steam turbines need at least 30 minutes. The prototype generated 10 MW and is approximately 10% the size of a comparable steam turbine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/601218/desk-size-turbine-could-power-a-town/#/set/id/601246/|title=Desk-Size Turbine Could Power a Town|last=Talbot|first=David|date=April 11, 2016|website=MIT Technology Review|access-date=2016-04-13}}</ref>
Further, due to its superior thermal stability and non-flammability, direct heat exchange from high temperature sources is possible, permitting higher working fluid temperatures and therefore higher cycle efficiency. And unlike two-phase flow, s{{chem|CO|2}}’s single-phase nature eliminates the necessity of a heat input for phase change that is required for the water to steam conversion, thereby also eliminating associated [[Fatigue (material)|thermal fatigue]] and corrosion.<ref>{{Cite web|url =http://breakingenergy.com/2014/11/24/supercritical-carbon-dioxide-power-cycles-starting-to-hit-the-market/|title =Supercritical Carbon Dioxide Power Cycles Starting to Hit the Market|date =|accessdate =|website =Breaking Energy|publisher =|last =|first =}}</ref>
Despite the promise of substantially higher efficiency and lower capital costs, the use of s{{chem|CO|2}} presents material selection and design issues. Materials in power generation components must display resistance to damage caused by [[Thermal resistance|high-temperature]], [[Anti-corrosion|oxidation]] and [[Creep (deformation)#Preventing creep|creep]]. Candidate materials that meet these property and performance goals include incumbent alloys in power generation, such as nickel-based superalloys for turbomachinery components and [[austenitic stainless steel]]s for piping. Components within s{{chem|CO|2}} Brayton loops suffer from corrosion and erosion, specifically erosion in turbomachinery and recuperative heat exchanger components and intergranular corrosion and pitting in the piping.<ref>{{Cite web|url =http://energy.sandia.gov/wp-content/gallery/uploads/SAND-2014-0602C.pdf|title =Corrosion and Erosion Behavior in s{{chem|CO|2}} Power Cycles|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =Sandia National Laboratories|last =|first =}}</ref>
Testing has been conducted on candidate Ni-based alloys, austenitic steels, ferritic steels and ceramics for corrosion resistance in s{{chem|CO|2}} cycles. The interest in these materials derive from their formation of protective surface oxide layers in the presence of carbon dioxide, however in most cases further evaluation of the reaction mechanics and corrosion/erosion kinetics and mechanisms is required, as none of the materials meet the necessary goals.<ref>{{Cite web|url =http://www.swri.org/4org/d18/sCO2/papers2014/materials/61-Pint.pdf|title =THE EFFECT OF TEMPERATURE ON THE sCO2 COMPATIBILITY OF CONVENTIONAL STRUCTURAL ALLOYS|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =The 4th International Symposium - Supercritical CO2 Power Cycles|last =|first =}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url =https://curve.carleton.ca/system/files/etd/e721cac4-dfdd-4490-985c-f519efec6426/etd_pdf/123e849e0ffc3b9bc8249b63b32d1738/parks-corrosionofcandidatehightemperaturealloys.pdf|title =Corrosion of Candidate High Temperature Alloys in Supercritical Carbon Dioxide|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =Ottawa-Carleton Institute for Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering|last =J. Parks|first =Curtis}}</ref>
====Other ==== Work is underway to develop a s{{chem|CO|2}} [[closed-cycle gas turbine]] to operate at temperatures near 550 °C. This would have implications for bulk thermal and nuclear generation of electricity, because the supercritical properties of carbon dioxide at above 500 °C and 20 MPa enable thermal efficiencies approaching 45 percent. This could increase the electrical power produced per unit of fuel required by 40 percent or more. Given the volume of carbon fuels used in producing electricity, the environmental impact of cycle efficiency increases would be significant.<ref>V. Dostal, M.J. Driscoll, P. Hejzlar, {{cite web |url=http://web.mit.edu/jessiek/MacData/afs.course.lockers/22/22.33/www/dostal.pdf |title=A Supercritical Carbon Dioxide Cycle for Next Generation Nuclear Reactors |accessdate=2007-11-20 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101227172513/http://web.mit.edu/jessiek/MacData/afs.course.lockers/22/22.33/www/dostal.pdf |archivedate=December 27, 2010 |df= }} ''MIT-ANP-Series'', MIT-ANP-TR-100 (2004)</ref>
Supercritical {{chem|CO|2}} is an emerging natural refrigerant, used in new, low carbon solutions for domestic [[heat pump]]s. Supercritical {{chem|CO|2}} heat pumps are commercially marketed in Asia. [[EcoCute]] systems from Japan, developed by Mayekawa, develop high temperature domestic water with small inputs of electric power by moving heat into the system from the surroundings.<ref>{{cite web|title=Heat Pumps|url=http://www.mayekawa.com/products/heat_pumps/|website=Mayekawa Manufacturing Company (Mycom)|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref>
Supercritical {{chem|CO|2}} has been used since the 1980s to enhance recovery in mature oil fields.
"[[Clean coal]]" technologies are emerging that could combine such enhanced recovery methods with [[carbon sequestration]]. Using [[gasifier]]s instead of conventional furnaces, coal and water is reduced to hydrogen gas, carbon dioxide and ash. This hydrogen gas can be used to produce electrical power In [[combined cycle]] gas turbines, {{chem|CO|2}} is captured, compressed to the supercritical state and injected into geological storage, possibly into existing oil fields to improve yields. The unique properties of s{{chem|CO|2}} ensure that it remains out of the atmosphere.<ref>[http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=10922&page=84 "The Hydrogen Economy: Opportunities, Costs, Barriers, and R&D Needs"], p. 84 (2004)</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=FutureGen 2.0 Project |url=http://futuregenalliance.org/futuregen-2-0-project/ |website=FutureGen Alliance |accessdate=7 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150210090013/http://futuregenalliance.org/futuregen-2-0-project/ |archivedate=10 February 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.zero.no/transport/bio/fischer-tropsch-reactor-fed-by-syngas Øyvind Vessia: "Fischer- Tropsch reactor fed by syngas"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929003817/http://www.zero.no/transport/bio/fischer-tropsch-reactor-fed-by-syngas |date=2007-09-29 }}</ref>
Supercritical {{chem|CO|2}} could be used as a working fluid in [[Enhanced Geothermal Systems|enhanced geothermal systems]]. Possible advantages compared to water include higher energy yield resulting from its lower viscosity, better chemical interaction, {{chem|CO|2}} storage through fluid loss and higher temperature limit. As of 2011, the concept had not been tested in the field.<ref>K Pruess(2006), [http://www.geothermal-energy.org/pdf/IGAstandard/SGW/2000/Brown.pdf "A hot dry rock geothermal energy concept utilizing s{{chem|CO|2}} instead of water"]</ref><ref>Donald W. Brown(2000), [http://geothermal.stanford.edu/pdf/SGW/2006/Pruess.pdf "On the feasibility of using s{{chem|CO|2}} as heat transmission fluid in an engineered hot dry rock geothermal system"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060904044609/http://geothermal.stanford.edu/pdf/SGW/2006/Pruess.pdf |date=2006-09-04 }}</ref><ref>K Pruess(2007)[http://escholarship.org/uc/item/1fr9q7q8;jsessionid=B03E54A3A0D99066247DEAA1841D33A8 Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS) comparing water with {{chem|CO|2}} as heat transmission fluids"]</ref><ref>J Apps(2011), [http://pangea.stanford.edu/ERE/pdf/IGAstandard/SGW/2011/apps.pdf "Modeling geochemical processes in enhanced geothermal systems with {{chem|CO|2}} as heat transfert fluid"]</ref><ref>http://earthsciences.typepad.com/blog/2011/06/achieving-carbon-sequestration-and-geothermal-energy-production-a-win-win.html ESD News and Events "Achieving Carbon Sequestration and Geothermal Energy Production: A Win-Win!"</ref>
===Aerogel production=== Supercritical carbon dioxide is used in the production of silica, carbon and metal based [[aerogels]]. For example, silicon dioxide gel is formed and then exposed to s{{chem|CO|2}}. When the {{chem|CO|2}} goes supercritical, all surface tension is removed, allowing the liquid to leave the aerogel and produce nanometer sized pores.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aerogel.org/?p=345|title=Aerogel.org » Supercritical Drying|publisher=}}</ref>
===Sterilization of biomedical materials=== Supercritical {{chem|CO|2}} is an alternative for terminal sterilization of biological materials and medical devices with combination of the additive [[peracetic acid]] (PAA). Supercritical {{chem|CO|2}} does not sterilize the media, because it does not kill the spores of microorganisms. Moreover, this process is gentle, as the morphology, ultrastructure and protein profiles of inactivated microbes are preserved.<ref>A.White, D. Burns, T.W. Christensen, [http://www.novasterilis.com/technology/images/PDFS/BIOTEC_4178.pdf "Effective terminal sterilization using supercritical carbon dioxide"]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}, ''Journal of Biotechnology''</ref>
===Cleaning=== Supercritical {{chem|CO|2}} is used in certain industrial [[carbon dioxide cleaning|cleaning processes]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox Airliner accident | image= Boeing 727-2F2-Adv, Turkish Airlines AN1003546.jpg | caption=The aircraft involved in the accident, 1981. | Name= Turkish Airlines Flight 158 | Date= 16 January 1983 | summary= Runway undershot in bad weather conditions | occurrence_type = Accident | Site= near [[Esenboğa International Airport|Ankara Esenboğa Airport]], Turkey | Coordinates= {{Coord|40|06|46.8|N|32|58|48|E|type:event|display=inline}} | Fatalities= 47 | Injuries= 20 | Survivors= 20 | Origin= [[Orly Airport]], Paris, France | Stopover= [[Atatürk International Airport|Istanbul Yeşilköy Airport]], Turkey | Destination= Ankara Esenboğa Airport, Turkey | Aircraft Type= [[Boeing 727|Boeing 727-2F2]] | Operator= [[Turkish Airlines]] | Tail Number= TC-JBR | Passengers= 60 | Crew= 7 | Ship name= ''Afyon'' }}
'''Turkish Airlines Flight 158''' was a scheduled domestic passenger flight from [[Istanbul Atatürk Airport|Istanbul Yeşilköy Airport]] to [[Esenboğa International Airport|Ankara Esenboğa Airport]], Turkey. On 16 January 1983, the aircraft operating the flight, a [[Boeing 727-200]], landed about {{convert|50|m|ft}} short of the runway at its destination airport in driving snow, broke up and caught fire.<ref name="asn">{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19830116-1 |publisher=Aviation Safety Network |title=Aircraft accident Boeing 727-2F2 TC-JBR Ankara |accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="byegm">{{cite web|url=http://www.byegm.gov.tr/YAYINLARIMIZ/AyinTarihi/1983/ocak1983.htm |publisher=Governmental Press and Information Office |title=Ayın Tarihi-Ocak 1983 |language=Turkish |accessdate=3 January 2009}}</ref> Of the 67 occupants on board, 47 perished.
==Aircraft== The aircraft, a [[Boeing 727|Boeing 727-2F2]] with three [[Pratt & Whitney JT8D|Pratt & Whitney JT8D-15]] [[turbofan]] [[jet engine]]s, was built by [[Boeing]] with manufacturer serial number 21603/1389, and made its first flight in 1978.<ref name="asn" />
==Crew and passengers== The aircraft had 7 crew and 60 passengers on board. 47 passengers were killed, all the crew and 13 passengers survived the accident with injuries.<ref name="asn" /><ref name="byegm" />

[[file:Zero Power Physics Reactor 001.jpg|thumb|The Zero Power Physics Reactor.]] The '''Zero Power Physics Reactor''' or '''ZPPR''' (originally named '''Zero Power Plutonium Reactor''') was a nuclear reactor located at the [[Idaho National Laboratory]], Idaho, USA.<ref name="ebr1">[http://www.ne.anl.gov/About/reactors/frt.shtml#fragment-7 ZPPR (Zero Power Physics Reactor)], Reactors designed by [[Argonne National Laboratory]]</ref>
ZPPR ran only at extremely low power, for testing nuclear reactor designs. ZPPR was operated as a critical facility from April 18, 1969 until 1990.
